It should be applied by the learned master in the heart: <hi rend="caps">oṁ saṁ namaḥ</hi>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="4">It cannot be known, it cannot be accomplished: it is only splendour, beyond the [reach of the] senses. Exceedingly brilliant on account of its inactive state, the Spirit abides in the breast.<note>Here I translate <foreign>pauruṣo</foreign> as if it were <foreign>puruṣo</foreign> (contrast 3.16d).</note>
.</p>
.
.<p>Above that there is the station called Tapoloka, the place of the reverend Brahmā. The seed-syllable there is Vāmadeva. It is spoken about as Inner Soul. Its appearance is splendour only. It is not recognised by the senses. It does not act, it is not acted upon.<note>Or: ‘it does not cause, it is not caused’.</note> It is the abode of the Spirit. .</p>
2700
.
.<p>Above that there is the station called Satyaloka, the abode of the reverend Rudra. There the seed syllable is Īśāna. It is the Supreme Soul. It is excellent. It is the abode of the Brahmamantras. It is the <foreign>Soul without superior</foreign>. It is what is called the <foreign>state of sovereignty</foreign>. Its appearance is transparent. It should be applied by the learned master to the lowest part of the throat: <hi rend="caps">oṁ īṁ namaḥ</hi>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="6">He should apply to the throat—the City of Śiva—the syllable <hi rend="caps">a</hi>, [which is] Śiva, spotless, void, supreme, free from disease, [existing] in unmanifest form in all the beings.

2705<p>Above that there is the station called ‘City of Śiva’, the abode of the Lord Śiva. There the seed-syllable is <hi rend="caps">a</hi>. It is spoken about as Supra-Soul, clear and empty. Its name is Śiva. It is excellent, devoid<ptr target="kasurudan1"/> of pleasure and pain,<note>Often occurring<ptr target="kasurudan1fn"/> in combination with <foreign>sukhaduhkha</foreign> (cf. 1.29, 4.34, 9.17, 10.2), <foreign>kasurudan</foreign> seems to mean ‘free from’, ‘devoid of’, ‘not affected by’, ‘abandoned by’. 2730<p rend="stanza" n="14">That<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">2.14</ref></seg> which has no form, no colour, no taste, no smell, no sound, no touch, which is free of disease, unfathomable, without beginning, middle, and end, unmeasurable, unmixed, without limbs, unconstructed,<note>Assuming that <foreign>aracana</foreign> is here understood as the equivalent of <foreign>aracita</foreign>.</note> without a second, unmoving, without external marks, imperishable, undecaying, without motion, without desire, not experiencing [incarnation in a] human womb, birth, and death, having no disease, having no sorrow, having no feelings, having no stain, having no suffering, having no time, without space, without year, season, month, day and night, without being apportioned by the [three] junctures [of the day], having no hour,<note>A <foreign>muhūrta</foreign> is the 30th parth of the day, consisting in 48 minutes.</note> not abiding in any time of the day, having neither the summer semester, the winter semester, or the equinox, without<ptr target="blinking"/> instant,<note>According<ptr target="blinkingfn"/> to MW, <foreign>animeṣa</foreign> is an equivalent of <foreign>animiṣa</foreign>, ‘not winking, looking steadily, vigilant’ (compare <foreign>nirnimeṣa</foreign>, ‘not twinkling, not closing the eye’), from <foreign>nimiṣa</foreign>, ‘shutting the eye, twinkling, winking [...] (also as a measure of time i.e. a moment’). In this context, i.e. after a series of expressions indicating the absence of divisions of time, this word was probably intended as ‘having no instants’; the exegesis glosses it as ‘there is no blinking in it’ (<foreign>tan hana kәḍap iriya</foreign>).</note> pacified, being spirit, without junctures, solitary, void, fixed, supreme, truthful, <sic>vidhitāṁ| na</sic> void beyond the void, clear, the state of isolation, without a support, benign, release, without unbelief, having no dychotomizing thoughts, having no mental constructs, the state of extinction, the Supreme Brahman, without form, having no fear, immortal—this state of Brahman, He is God, He is the <foreign>summum bonum</foreign>, He is Parameśvara, He is the Supreme Soul, He is the non plus ultra, whose senses have disappeared; that is the End of Brahma, the state of release, unobstructed, free from disease, the supreme extinction, without modifications, without limits, the supreme abode,<ptr target="anaśravam"/> unpolluted;<note><foreign>anāśravaṁ</foreign><ptr target="anaśravamfn"/> derives<ptr target="anaśravamfn"/> from <foreign>āśrava</foreign>, a Buddhist term—probably a Sanskritization, found in Mahāyāna and Abhidharmic literature, of the Pāli <foreign>āsava</foreign>, whose synonym is <foreign>ogha</foreign> or ‘floods’—literally meaning ‘outflow’, and denoting ‘a group of basic impurities or defilements which are the cause of repeated rebirth’ (Keown 2003).</note> this very [principle] is Mahādeva, more pervasive, more subtle, greater, wider, without a body, beyond the senses, the eternally beneficial ambrosia, pure, without parts, perpetual; He Himself is the mother, the father, the kinsman, the relative, the friend, the teacher, the God, very powerful, Mahādeva!</p>
.
.
.
.<p><foreign>na rūpa\ṁm</foreign>,<note>In this Old Javanese dyad I do not translate the Sanskrit lemmas, which are often virtually identical to their Old Javanese renderings, to avoid repetition.</note> It has no form; <foreign>na varṇa\ṁm</foreign>, It has no colour; <foreign>na rasa\ṁm</foreign>, It has no taste; <foreign>na gandha\ṁm</foreign>, It has no smell; <foreign>na śabda\ṁm</foreign>, It has no sound; <foreign>asparśam</foreign>, It has no touch; <foreign>anāmaya\ṁm</foreign>, It is not affected by suffering; <foreign>acintya\ṁm</foreign>, It is not made object of thought; <foreign>anādimadhyāntam</foreign>, having no beginning, middle, and end; <foreign>amita\ṁm</foreign>, having no delimitation; <foreign>asaṅkīrṇa\ṁm</foreign>, not mixed; <foreign>agātram</foreign>, having no body; <foreign>aracanam</foreign>, not attached to form and colour; <foreign>advitīyam</foreign>, there is none who surpasses It as being Supreme; <foreign>acalita\ṁm</foreign>, without movement; <foreign>aliṅgakam</foreign>, there is no external mark in It; <foreign>acyuta\ṁm</foreign>, not lacking [anything];<note>This translation of <foreign>tar makasurudan</foreign>, being a gloss of <foreign>acyutam</foreign> (‘imperishable, permanent’), derives from the meaning that this word seemingly has elsewhere in the text: cf. <foreign>kasurudan</foreign> in 2.6 and <foreign>tar pakasurudan</foreign> in 4.13 and fn. <ref>kasurudan1fn</ref> on p. <ref>kasurudan1</ref>, discussing <foreign>kasurudan</foreign>).</note> <foreign>akṣaya\ṁm</foreign>, not diminishing; <foreign>nirgata\ṁm</foreign>, without motion; <foreign>aspr̥ha\ṁm</foreign>, not desiring; <foreign>agarbhajanmamaraṇam</foreign>, not being affected by [incarnation in a] human womb, birth, and death; <foreign>aroga\ṁm</foreign>, there is no affliction in It; <foreign>aśoka\ṁm</foreign>, not being affected by sadness; <foreign>avedanam</foreign>, not experiencing affliction; <foreign>asaṅsāra\ṁm</foreign>, not experiencing suffering; <foreign>nirmala\ṁm</foreign>, not being stained; <foreign>na kāla\ṁm</foreign>, having no time; <foreign>nākāśam</foreign>, having no space; <foreign>na saṁvatsarartumāsāhorātra</foreign>, having no year, having no season, having no month, having no day and night; <foreign>asandhyāṅśam</foreign>, not apportioned by the [three] junctures [of the day]; <foreign>na muhūrta\ṁm</foreign>, having no hour; <foreign>na velakaṣṭha\ṁm</foreign>, not abiding in any time of the day; <foreign>nottarāyana\ṁm</foreign>, not having the winter semester; <foreign>na dakṣiṇāyana\ṁm</foreign>, not having the summer semester; <foreign>na vaiṣuva\ṁm</foreign>, having no equinoctial points; <foreign>animeṣa\ṁm</foreign>, there is no blinking in It;<note>cf. fn. <ref>blinkingfn</ref>, p. <ref>blinking</ref>.</note> <foreign>śānta\ṁm</foreign>, pacified; <sic>...</sic> <foreign>śūnya\ṁm</foreign>, void; <foreign>dhruva\ṁm</foreign>, with concentrated attention;<note>The meaning of the Sanskrit word <foreign>dhruva</foreign> in this context is ‘fixed, firm, immovable, unchangeable, constant, lasting, permanent, eternal’ (MW); however, the exegesis glosses it as <foreign>meṅәt</foreign> (OJED: ‘to revolve (in one’s mind), be aware of, know or understand clearly, consider; to remember, recall; to be conscious, regain consciousness, with concentrated attention’). It seems as if the commentator understood it in the sense of <foreign>dhīra</foreign>/<foreign>dhairya</foreign> ‘intelligence; firmness, constancy’ (MW).</note> <foreign>para\ṁm</foreign>, supreme; <foreign>satya\ṁm</foreign>, sincere; <sic><foreign>vīta\ṁm</foreign></sic> <foreign>śūnyātiśūnyam</foreign> <sic>...</sic>; <foreign>svaccha\ṁm</foreign>, clear; <foreign>kaivalya\ṁm</foreign>, the state of isolation; <foreign>nirāśrayam</foreign>, having no support; <foreign>śiva\ṁm</foreign>, It is called Śiva (‘benign’); <foreign>mokṣa\ṁm</foreign>, It is the state of release; <foreign>niraśraddha\ṁm</foreign>, not disliking;<note>The word <foreign>niraśraddham</foreign> literally means ‘one not deprived of faith’, a sense that does not seem to be reflected by the Old Javanese gloss <foreign>tar elik</foreign> ‘not disliking/hating’, if not in a very general sense (i.e., one who has faith does not dislike the scriptures, the master, etc.). cf. BndP (OJ) 76, where <foreign>tar elik</foreign> glosses <foreign>anabhidveṣa</foreign> (<foreign>anabhidveṣa ṅaranya tar elik riṅ melik iriya</foreign>).</note> <sic>...</sic> <foreign>nirbāṇam</foreign>, It is the state of release; <foreign>paraṁ brahma</foreign>, It is the Supreme among [the various levels of the] Brahman; <foreign>nirākāram</foreign>, having no form; <foreign>na bhayam</foreign>, being unaffected by fear; <foreign>amr̥ta\ṁm</foreign>, being unaffected by death; <foreign>etaṁ brahmapada\ṁm</foreign>, thus is Its form, the State of Brahman, as It is called; <foreign>sa eṣa devaḥ</foreign>, He is God; <foreign>saḥ paramārthaḥ</foreign>, He is the Summum Bonum; <foreign>saḥ maheśvaraḥ</foreign>,<note>The corresponding Sanskrit portion has <foreign>parameśvara</foreign>. cf. dyad 1, where the Sanskrit lemma and its Old Javanese gloss read <foreign>maheśvara</foreign> against <foreign>parameśvara</foreign> in the verse.</note> He is Maheśvara; <foreign>saḥ paramātmā</foreign>, He is the Supreme Soul; <foreign>saḥ śreṣṭhaḥ</foreign>, He is excellent; <foreign>vigatendriyaḥ</foreign>, there are no senses in Him;<note>I have emended <foreign>vigatar atīndriyaḥ| tan hanar atīndriye sira</foreign> to <foreign>vigatendriyaḥ| tan hanendriye sira</foreign> on the basis of the corresponding Sanskrit portion, which has <foreign>vigatendriyaḥ</foreign> (‘whose senses have disappeared’—a synonym of <foreign>nirindriyaḥ</foreign>), as well as of context. For the gloss of Sanskrit <foreign>vigata</foreign> as <foreign>tan aneriya</foreign> ‘there is not in him’ (being equivalent to <foreign>tan hana ... i sira</foreign> in this passage), see <foreign>Uttarakāṇḍa</foreign> 16.24 (quoted in OJED s.v. <foreign>vigata</foreign>): <foreign>bhīṣaṇa kapva ṅaraniṅ katatakut, vigata tan haneriya</foreign>.</note> <foreign>tad brahmānta\ṁm</foreign>, He is the State of the End of Brahman; <foreign>mokṣa\ṁm</foreign>, He is the state of release; <foreign>aniruddha\ṁm</foreign>, is not affected by pleasure and pain; <foreign>nirāmaya\ṁm</foreign>, not affected by sorrow; <foreign>paran nirbāṇam</foreign>, He is the supreme extinction; <foreign>nirvikāra\ṁm</foreign>, He is not affected by modifications—its meaning is ‘without cracks’;<note>OJED glosses <foreign>rәṅat</foreign> as ‘cleft, crack, crevice, fissure; split, cleft, cracked’. Alternatively, one could emend <foreign>kalīṅanira</foreign> to <foreign>kahīṅanira</foreign>, and obtain a more or less appropriate gloss of <foreign>amaryāda</foreign> (‘its limits are not split’), which could then be supplied before rather than after it.</note> <foreign>a\-mar\-yā\-da\ṁm</foreign>, the supreme more excellent than the excellent; <foreign>paraṁ pada\ṁm</foreign>, He is the supreme abode; <foreign>anāśrava\ṁm</foreign>, not flowing;<note>The Old<ptr target="anasravafn2"/> Javanese gloss of <foreign>anāśrava</foreign> follows the literal meaning of <foreign>āśrava</foreign>, based on the stem <foreign>āsru</foreign> ‘flow’ (cf. fn. <ref>anaśravamfn</ref>, p. <ref>anaśravamfn</ref>).</note> <foreign>eṣa eva mahādevaḥ</foreign>, He is called Mahādeva; <foreign>vyāpīya\ṁm</foreign>, He pervades the whole universe; <foreign>sūkṣmīya\ṁm</foreign>, He is the epitome of subtleness; <foreign>māhīya\ṁm</foreign>, <foreign>varīya\ṁm</foreign>, He is exceptional in greatness indeed; <foreign>vitanuḥ</foreign>, He does not have a body; <foreign>atīndriyaḥ</foreign>, He is superior in being unseen; <foreign>hitasadāmr̥taḥ</foreign>, He is the eternally blissful ambrosia; <foreign>śuddhaḥ</foreign>, He is not stained; <foreign>niṣkala\ṁm</foreign>, He is without parts; <foreign>śāśvataḥ</foreign>, He is eternal; <foreign>sa eva mātā</foreign>, He is the mother; <foreign>sa eva pitā</foreign>, He is the father; <foreign>saḥ vandhuḥ</foreign>, He is the relative, <foreign>saḥ svajanaḥ</foreign>, He is the kinsman; <foreign>saḥ mitraḥ</foreign>, He is the friend; <foreign>saḥ guruḥ</foreign>, He is the teacher; <foreign>saḥ devaḥ</foreign>, He is God; <foreign>saḥ mahārdhikaḥ</foreign>, He is very powerful. He whose condition is such, <foreign>mahādeva iti</foreign>—He is the Lord Mahādeva by name!</p>
2735
. <p rend="stanza" n="15">
.Having<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>moonpotscomm</ref></seg> known that Mahādeva is pervasive within all embodied beings like space within pots, one reaches supportless liberation.
.</p>
.<p>
2740The Leader among Yogins knows that the Lord Mahādeva pervades all the embodied beings like the space pervades all the embodied beings. In the same way, the multiple pots are the places where the single moon resides. Thus is how non-manifestation,<note>Here<ptr target="asad"/> I translate <foreign>nora</foreign> as ‘non-manifestation’ instead of ‘non-existence’: cf. Acri 2017: 588–590.</note> the final destination of everything, is compressed in a limited space.<note>Or: ‘hidden’? cf. OJED 1772 s.v. *<foreign>simpәn</foreign>: ‘brought together in a limited space, grouped together, compressed, in a limited number, containing the basic essentials; put away, hidden’.</note> [Being] the epitome of superiority over the group of six [inner stains], he reaches the stage of release. His release is without boundaries.</p>
. <p rend="stanza" n="16">In like manner Śiva, alone, resides in the eightfold condition of the gods,<note>I interpret this <foreign>pada</foreign> as an inversed split compound, as if it were <foreign>aṣṭasthānadeveṣu tathā</foreign>. I take this to be a reference to the eight manifestations of Śiva.</note> in the human beings, whose condition is one, and in the lower organic world, whose conditions are five.
.</p>
.<p>
.The divinities, their divisions are eight: Brahmā, Prajāpati, Mahendra, Soma, the Gandharvas, the Yakṣas, the Pretas, the Pīśācas. Thus are their divisions. Human beings are single. And yet [there are] the four births, their number [is as follows]: Brahmins, warriors, workers, servants. Thus are what are called the four births. As for the lower organic world, five are its divisions: domestic animals, wild animals, birds, creeping creatures, and plants. Such are its divisions. The condition of the Lord Śiva [is that] He is one; supreme, He abides in the entire universe.</p>
2745 <p rend="stanza" n="17">Śiva, subtle, omnipervasive, is not perceived by the senses of the beings, like the atmosphere. He is unfathomable, ungraspable by the mind.
.</p>
.
.<p>The Lord Śiva is pervasive. He is subtle, not affected by thought. He is like the space, not grasped by the mind and the senses.</p><p rend="stanza" n="18">Like<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>fireinwoodcomm</ref></seg> the fire [residing] in every log is not perceived on account of its subtlety, Mahādeva is not perceived in every being on account of its subtlety.
.</p>
2750
.<p>The reverend Fire is in every piece of wood, but it is not seen because of its subtlety; <foreign>yathā</foreign>—like the atmosphere, in the same way is the Lord Mahādeva as he exists in all embodied beings. However, He is not grasped because of His subtlety.</p><p rend="stanza" n="19">Through<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>fireinwoodcomm</ref></seg> the means of rubbing the fire-stick, the fire comes to exist in the world. In the same manner, through the means [of] the yoga of gnosis, the one Lord [becomes] double.
.</p>
.
.<p>When the wood is used as a means, being rubbed tenaciously, the fire comes out here in the world. Just in the same manner the Lord [comes to exist], when it is visualized by means of the gnosis. You should use yoga as the means.</p><p rend="stanza" n="20">Having<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>fireinwoodcomm</ref></seg> clearly perceived the spotless God in the mind [as residing] in all embodied beings like a blazing fire, one reaches the supreme goal.
2755</p>
.
.<p>The reverend Leader among Yogins visualizes the Lord [with] the knowledge in his mind. His appearance is spotless, [He] resides visibly in all the embodied beings. Like the splendour of the fire, His form shines. When the Lord is visualized [in this manner] by the Leader among Yogins, he reaches the state of liberation.</p>
.
.<p>
2760
.<hi rend="italic">Thus [ends] the scripture entitled ‘The Secret Doctrine on Brahman’, Chapter 2.</hi>
.</p>
.</div>
. <div>
2765
.<head>The Secret Doctrine on Brahman, Chapter 3</head>
.<p rend="stanza" n="1">Spotless,<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>purusajyoti</ref></seg> Rudra has the essence of Śiva; patient,<note>MW considers <foreign>kṣānta</foreign> a name/epithet of Śiva. Alternatively, one could emend it to <foreign>śānto</foreign>, ‘pacified’.</note> [He is] the Life Principle, exceedingly subtle.<note>Or: ‘beyond the immaterial’.</note> From Him the Spirit was born. Having the appearance of the Sun, it is the Lord of everything.
.</p>
.
2770
.<p>The Lord Rudra is one in being with Lord Śiva. He is spotless. He is extremely subtle. From the Lord Rudra, the Spirit was born. Its essence is Brahmā. Being like the splendour of the sun, it is the Lord.</p><p rend="stanza" n="2">The Unevolved was born. It is to be known as being like a sesame seed,<note>I interpret <foreign>kr̥ṣṇakevā</foreign>° as <foreign>kr̥ṣṇakā</foreign> (= <foreign>kr̥ṣṇikā</foreign>) + <foreign>iva</foreign>, i.e. a reference to the well-known analogy of Unevolved Matter as the seed of everything that exists (cf. infra, 3.19). Alternatively, <foreign>kr̥ṣṇaka</foreign> here could simply mean ‘black’ (in which case, <foreign>kr̥ṣṇakevā</foreign>° would be an instance of double <foreign>sandhi</foreign>: <foreign>kr̥ṣṇakaḥ</foreign> + <foreign>eva</foreign>). Neither of the two meanings are reflected in the exegesis.</note> subtle, eternal, beyond the senses, unfathomable, difficult to grasp, consisting of <foreign>tamas</foreign>, insentient.
.</p>
.
.
2775<p>From the Spirit the Unevolved was born. Its reality is Viṣṇu. Its existence is eternal. It cannot be grasped by the senses. It cannot be fathomed. It is difficult to be known. It consists of <foreign>tamas</foreign>. It is devoid of sentience.</p><p rend="stanza" n="3">Thereafter, from the Unevolved the Intellect was born, yellowish, consisting of <foreign>sattva</foreign>. From that [Intellect] the Passion (i.e., Self-Identity) was born, red in colour, consisting of <foreign>rajas</foreign>.
.</p>
.
.<p>From the Unevolved, the Intellect was born. Its colour is yellow. Its nature is <foreign>sattva</foreign>. It is eminent. From the Intellect, the Self-Identity was born. Its colour is red. Its nature is <foreign>rajas</foreign>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="4">From<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.4</ref></seg> that Passionate [Self-Identity] what is black in colour, made of <foreign>tamas</foreign> (i.e., the series of the Five Subtle Elements), was born. That whose essence is ideation and thought (i.e., \manas), the origin of the series [of the Five Gross Elements], was born.
.</p>
2780
.<p>From the Self-Identity, the Five Subtle Elements were born. Their colour is black. Their nature is <foreign>tamas</foreign>. From the Five Subtle Elements the Sense-Mind was born.
. Its function is ideation, that is to say, to ideate (<foreign>manaṅkalpa</foreign>).<note>I have emended <foreign>manah kalpa</foreign> to <foreign>manaṅkalpa</foreign>. cf. fn. <ref>manangkalpafn2</ref> on dyad 3.13, as well as dyads 3.30 and 3.60.</note> Its nature is to consider<note><foreign>Mamilaṅ</foreign>, glossed by OJED (s.v. <foreign>amilaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>umilaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>winilaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>kawilaṅ</foreign>) as ‘to count, enumerate, calculate, consider one by one, take into account, consider’. This word may actually be a gloss of <foreign>gaṇa</foreign> in <foreign>gaṇasambhava</foreign>, interpreted by the commentator in the sense of ‘to count, to calculate’, as if it were <foreign>gaṇita</foreign> (whereas I have taken it to refer to either the series of the Five Gross Elements (cf. the next dyad), or perhaps the Sixteen Evolutes (cf. supra, pp. <ref>ganasambhava1</ref>, <ref>ganasambhava2</ref>).</note> and to imagine. Such is its outcome: ideation and deliberating.</p><p rend="stanza" n="5">From<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.5-7</ref></seg> that [Sense-Mind] the Space was born—external, relating to sound, without attributes. From that the Wind [was born]—whose essence is touch, whose essence are the qualities of sound and touch.
.</p>
.
2785<p>From the Sense-Mind the Space was born. It is external. Its quality is sound. From the Space the Wind was born. Its qualities are sound and touch.</p><p rend="stanza" n="6">From Wind, Fire is produced, possessing sound, touch, and form.<note>I take <foreign>virūpa</foreign> to be the same as <foreign>rūpa</foreign> (cf. 3.7a).</note> From that Water [is produced], whose essence consists of taste, form, sound, and touch.<note>I take <foreign>rasarūpaśabdasparśaḥ ... salilātmakaḥ</foreign> to be an irregular ‘split compound’ understood in the sense of <foreign>rasarūpaśabdasparśātmakaṁ salilaṁ</foreign>.</note>
.</p>
.
.<p>From Wind, Fire was born. Its qualities are sound, touch, and form. From Fire, Water was born. Its qualities are sound, touch, form, taste.</p><p rend="stanza" n="7">The Earth [was born from Water], declared to have sound, touch, and form, and possessing taste and odour. This is what is called ‘creation’, known as ‘the twelve’ and ‘the fivefold’.
.</p>
2790
.
.<p>From Water, Earth was born. Its qualities are sound, touch, form, taste, and odour. Thus are the ontic levels, twelve in number: Rudra, Spirit, Unevolved, Intellect, Self-identity, Five Subtle Elements, Sense-Mind, Space, Wind, Fire, Water, Earth. Thus are the ontic levels. Their seed-syllables are: <hi rend="caps">sa, ba, ta, a, i</hi>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="8">When<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>astamurticomm</ref></seg> those [Ontic Leves] combine together,<note>None of the meanings attested in Sanskrit dictionaries for <foreign>abhiyoga</foreign> seems appropriate here (for instance, MW glosses <foreign>abhiyogatva</foreign> as ‘application, energetic effort, exertion, perseverance in, constant practice (with loc. or inf.), attack, assault’, etc.). However, the context, as well as the Old Javanese gloss <foreign>kapasaṅan</foreign> (a <foreign>ka</foreign>-...-<foreign>an</foreign> construction, reflecting the -Sanskrit <foreign>tva</foreign> abstract suffix, from <foreign>pasaṅ</foreign>, among whose meanings are ‘putting together, joining up, applying, fixing up; that which joins up, which meets st.; that which is lying or put ready’, etc.), suggest that the intended meaning here must derive from the stem <foreign>yoga</foreign> in the sense of ‘yoking, fitting together’.</note> the body of the universe is produced. Śiva resides, alone, in everything that ever existed and does not exist [yet].<note>Having emended <foreign>tatra tatrāsin ābhūtaḥ</foreign> to <foreign>tatra tatrāsīn abhūtaḥ</foreign> (resulting in a <foreign>ra-vipulā</foreign>); alternatively, one could emend to <foreign>tatra tatrāsīn nābhūtaḥ</foreign>, ‘everything that ever existed and is not unreal’, or <foreign>tatra tatrāpi ca bhūtaḥ</foreign>, ‘existing in every one of those [ontic levels]’, which involves a more complex chain of mistakes, but has the merit of responding to the <foreign>siromuṅguh riṅ tattva kabeh</foreign> in the exegesis.</note>
.</p>
.
2795<p>The coming together of the ontic levels of Rudra etc. serves as the body of the whole universe. As for the Lord Śiva, He pervades the universe. He is supreme. He resides in all the ontic levels.</p><p rend="stanza" n="9">He<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>astamurticomm</ref></seg> who is the One [Lord] is called Śarva in the Earth, Bhava in the Water. He is known as Paśupati in the Fire, and Īśāna in the Wind.
.</p>
.
.<p>The divisions of the Lord when He resides in all the ontic levels are as follows: He is called Śarva when he resides in the Earth. He is called Bhava when He resides in the Water. He is called Paśupati when He resides in the reverend Agni (= Fire). He is called Īśāna when he resides in the Wind.</p><p rend="stanza" n="10">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>astamurticomm</ref></seg> Lord Bhīma is in the Space, Mahādeva in the Sense-Mind. Ugra is in the Subtle Elements, while Rudra is proclaimed to be in the Passionate (= Self-Identity).
.</p>
2800
.<p>He is called Bhīma when He is in the Space. He is endowed with the Eight Supernatural Powers. He is called Mahādeva when He is in the Sense-Mind, without a body. He is called Ugra when He is in the Subtle Elements. He is called Rudra when He is in the Passion, being the Self-Identity itself.<note>Or: ‘being the Self-Identity itself’.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="11">He<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>astamurticomm</ref></seg> should be known as Īśvara when He is in the Intellect. Dhātr̥ (= Brahmā), the Unevolved, resides in the Earth.<note>For the reconstruction of this <foreign>pāda</foreign>, cf. the following fn.</note> The Spirit, Brahman, is in the Consciousness. He is Maheśvara when He is the Cause.
.</p>
.
.<p>One should know as follows: the reverend Īśvara resides in the Intellect. The reverend Brahmā is [the] Unevolved; He resides in the earth.<note>Here the commentator, seemingly on the basis of the corrupt transmitted text, took <foreign>avyakto</foreign> (a synonym of Prak{\rd}ti) as an attribute of Dhāt{\rd}, and glossed <foreign>mahī</foreign> (‘the great one’, i.e. ‘earth’) as <foreign>pr̥thivī</foreign> (the same equation is found in the Old Javanese Bhīṣmaparva, p. 30: <foreign>pr̥thivī atah pradhāna ṅaranya</foreign>); however, the original <foreign>pāda</foreign> might have read <foreign>dhātāvyakte pratiṣṭhitaḥ</foreign>, ‘Dhāt{\rd} is established in the Unevolved’. Be this as it may, one would expect an association of Prak{\rd}ti with Viṣṇu rather than Brahmā (\cf, e.g., 2.3, 3.2, etc.).</note> The Spirit is the consciousness of the [embodied] beings. .<p>The Organs of Perception have been taught by the Lord Kapila as being fivefold in nature, for instance: Ear, Skin, Eye, Tongue, Nose. These are the Organs of Perception. Now, the Organs of Action, their number is five. Those I shall explain to you.</p><p rend="stanza" n="37">The Five Organs of Perception are produced in the [ontic level] whose essence is <foreign>sattva</foreign>.<note>I take <foreign>sāttvikāntav</foreign> to be an <foreign>āiśa</foreign> form corresponding to <foreign>sāttvikānte</foreign>, and <foreign>vijāyate</foreign> to be the equivalent of <foreign>vijanyante</foreign>, m.c.; however, by glossing it as <foreign>kavruhananta</foreign>, the exegesis seems to understand <foreign>vijñāyante</foreign>. One would expect the <foreign>sāttvika</foreign> to be the Intellect (cf. 3.3); however, here it may refer to the sattvic aspect of Self-Identity from which the Faculties of Perception arise.</note> Know the Five Organs of Action as being made of <foreign>tamas</foreign> and <foreign>rajas</foreign>.
.</p>
2900
.<p>Then, you all, you should know that the Five Organs of Perception, their nature is <foreign>sattva</foreign>. But the Five Organs of Action, their nature is <foreign>tamas</foreign> and <foreign>rajas</foreign>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="38">From<note>I take <foreign>śabdatanmātram</foreign> to be an Aiśa form for <foreign>śabdatanmātrāt</foreign> (cf. p. <ref>multipurpose</ref>), even though the exegesis here follows the copular construction of the Sanskrit.</note> the<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>adhibhutadhideva</ref></seg> Subtle Element of Sound [comes] the Mouth. [Its] deity is taught to be Īsvara. The object is what can be spoken. It is the origin of the God of Gods.
.</p>
.
.<p>The Mouth is the Subtle Element of Sound, [i.e.] what serves as its transformation. Its field of action is to speak what is proper. Its deity is the reverend Īśvara.</p><p rend="stanza" n="39">The Hand<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>adhibhutadhideva</ref></seg> is born from the Subtle Element of Touch. [Its] presiding deity is Indra.<note>I emend <foreign>pāṇīndriyādidevataḥ</foreign> to <foreign>pāṇir indro ’dhidevataḥ</foreign>, in the light of the context, the Sanskrit parallels, and the exegesis, where Indra is the deity associated with the hands. The mistake was probably caused by confusion between <foreign>indra</foreign> and <foreign>indriya</foreign> (‘sense’ or ‘organ’); cf. 3.59b, <foreign>pāṇīndrāpy ābhitr̥ptyate</foreign>, which I have tentatively emended to <foreign>pāṇir indro ’bhitr̥ptyate</foreign>.</note> Its object is what can be grasped. The [other] deity is the everlasting Vāyu.
2905</p>
.
.
.<p>The Hand, its cause is the Subtle Element of Touch.<note>On the basis of the context and the verse, I interpret the form <foreign>gavenya</foreign> as ‘its cause’, on the basis of OJED s.v. (<foreign>m</foreign>)<foreign>agave</foreign>, <foreign>pagave</foreign>, ‘(subst.) to make, do, perform; to cause’) rather than as ‘its product’ (OJED s.v. <foreign>gave</foreign>, <foreign>gavay</foreign> ‘work, task, occupation; work, product; [...] use, purpose’).</note> Its deity is the reverend Indra. Its field of action is to grab. Its other deity is Vāyu.<note>The mention of two deities in this dyad is odd, but may be explained by the fact that, while the presiding deity of the hand (a <foreign>karmendriya</foreign>) is Indra indeed (cf., e.g., MBh 12.301.4; TSam 7, etc.), Vāyu is associated with touch (a <foreign>buddhīndriya</foreign>) and skin: cf. Its object is what is excreted. He uses the form of Agni.
.</p>
2910

.<p>The Anus, its cause is the Subtle Element of Touch.<note>I emend the expression <foreign>ikaṅ</foreign> ... <foreign>ya</foreign> in the opening clauses of the glosses in dyads 3.40–42 to <foreign>ikaṅ</foreign> ... <foreign>gavenya</foreign>, so as to reflect the same structure of the exegesis in 3.39 (without the punctuation mark), as well as the expected sense, as required by the context and conveyed by the verses, whereby the Organs are not their respective Subtle Elements but rather their products.</note> The reverend Maitrī is its deity there in the body. .</p>

2915

2920<p>The two Feet, their cause is the Subtle Element of Smell. 2925<p>The Organs of Perception are five in number. The reverend Five Gross Elements are used by them as [means to generate] happiness. Such is the reality of what constitutes the body of all the incarnated beings. Its seed-syllable is taught to be Aghora. Such are the words of the learned master. <hi rend="caps">oṁ aṁ namaḥ</hi>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="44">Earth,<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>1.9</ref></seg> Water, Fire, Wind, Space, Sense-Mind, and the Ten Organs, [belonging to the] external [world], are the Sixteen Evolutes.
. </p>
.
.
.<p>Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, Space, Sense-Mind, and the Ten Organs, all of them are in the exterior [dimension of the human being and cosmos]. They are called the Sixteen Evolutes.</p><p rend="stanza" n="45">Flesh,<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>3.45-52</ref></seg> bones, muscles, bile, hair, bodily hair, nails, as well as the heart and so on—all of them are taught to be Earth, fivefold.<note>In<ptr target="pancadha"/> this dyad and those following thereupon, the series of bodily elements yield more than five items, thus giving rise to an inconsistency with <foreign>pañcadhā</foreign> (contrast the similar passage in the ŚKJ, where <foreign>pañcadhā</foreign> reflects a list of five bodily constituents: cf. my Commentary infra). This inconsistency appears to have been resolved by the exegesis by glossing <foreign>pañcadhā</foreign> as ‘the outcome of the Five Gross Elements’. Alternatively, it may convey the idea that the parts of the human body are made up by the Five Gross Elements, yet one in particular is prevalent in each one of them.</note>
2930 </p>
.
.<p>Further, I will teach you as follows: the flesh and bones, muscles, hair, hair of the legs, the ‘black’ (i.e., bile?),<note>The word <foreign>kr̥ṣṇa</foreign> is not attested in OJED with the meaning of a part of the body; etymologically, it seems to be connected with the ‘black humour’ or bile. By comparing this with similar lists of bodily organs found in Old Javanese-Balinese texts, one can see that the organ connected with black colour is <foreign>ampru</foreign>, which OJED glosses as ‘gall’, and which Balinese dictionaries gloss as both ‘gall’ and ‘bile’.</note> kidneys,<note>OJED glosses <foreign>vuṅsilan</foreign> as ‘scrotum’, but the two instances quoted there seem to mention internal organs, just like here. 2935<p>The blood, urine, sweat, saliva, bone marrow, brains: the nature of all of them is liquid. They are the water in the body. 2955 </p>

.<p>Ears, eyes, nose, heart, anus, reproductive organs, bones: all of them are Space.<note>The<ptr target="pancadha3"/> exegesis is idiosyncratic here, stating that the Space <foreign>is</foreign> the parts of the body, and not that it exists <foreign>in</foreign> them, as mentioned in the verse. 2960

2965<p>As for all their distributions, here is the progression as they are joined together, [as well as] their number and their [respective] destinations.</p><p rend="stanza" n="55">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>adhibhutadhideva</ref></seg> Nose satisfies itself with odours; Earth satisfies itself with food. 2980<p>The Genitals are satisfied in the domain of sensual pleasure. 2990<p>The Five Subtle Elements, they are satisfied with being divided. The Lord Ugra is satisfied in this manner. The Self-Identity is satisfied in relating [everything] to the I. The Lord Rudra is happy in this manner, due to its Constituents.<note>The 3rd person pronominal suffix -<foreign>nira</foreign>, used instead of -<foreign>nya</foreign>, seems odd, suggesting that the commentator might have understood it as referring to Rudra rather than to the Self-Identity.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="62">Intellect<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.14ab</ref>▷ <ref>adhibhutadhideva</ref></seg> [is satisfied with] determination. Īśvara, known as Brahman, [is the deity there]. The Unevolved [is satisfied] with [being] the material cause of those [ontic levels]. Viṣṇu becomes excellent in satisfaction.
. </p>
.
.
.<p>The Intellect is satisfied with determining.<note>I emend <foreign>ādhyātmaviṣaya</foreign> to <foreign>adhyavasāya</foreign> on the basis of the context, the ubiquitous association between <foreign>buddhi</foreign> and <foreign>adhyavasāya</foreign> in Sanskrit philosophico-religious literature (cf. supra, fn. <ref>adhyavasayafn</ref>), and the verse, whose reading <foreign>ādiḥ viṣayate</foreign> I have emended to <foreign>adhyavasāyate</foreign>: compare dyad 3.14, where <foreign>adhyavasānatvam</foreign> in the verse (emended from <foreign>ābhyāvaśānatvaṁ</foreign>) is glossed as <foreign>mādva viśaya</foreign>, which is apparently a corruption. I assume that this series of corruptions was engendered by a lack of familiarity by a scribe/redactor with the philosophical terminology expressed in the original dyads. But, of course, one could also imagine that the expression <foreign>ādhyātmaviṣaya</foreign> ‘the spiritual domain’ in the exegesis is authorial, being the result of the commentator’s idiosyncratic interpretation of <foreign>adhyavasāya</foreign>. cf. MBh app. 29c.171 to 12.308.191 (found in the same passage echoing dyads 3.23–25, 3.30–39, etc.), <foreign>buddhir adhyātmaṁ vyavasāyo ’dhibhūtaṁ brahmādhidaivataṁ</foreign>, containing both <foreign>vyavasāya</foreign> (= <foreign>a\-dhy\-a\-va\-sā\-ya</foreign>) and <foreign>adhyātma</foreign>, as well as MatPār VP 18.84c: <foreign>buddhir adhyātmabhāvena</foreign>.</note> The reverend Īśvara has as seed-syllables the Brahmamantras. 2995 </p>
.

As for the Lord Mahādeva, He is happy [with having] the condition of [Primary] Cause.</p><p rend="stanza" n="64">When the deitites are near their respective sensory objects, they burn all [those] objects up,<note>Even though the exegesis glosses <foreign>tāpayanti</foreign> as <foreign>gәsәṅana</foreign> (‘should be burnt’), it is not impossible that the <foreign>pada</foreign> actually read <foreign>tarpayanti</foreign>, being the causative of <foreign>tr̥p</foreign>, meaning ‘to satiate’, but also ‘to become satisfied’ (in the <foreign>ātmanepada</foreign>) and ‘to kindle’. .</p>

3000
.<p>The sensory objects, their nature is to be not far from the body. All of them should be burnt. When that happens, you are regarded as embodying the [supreme] deity.</p><p rend="stanza" n="65">O God, greatly subtle! 3005<p>Thus is the sequence of all the ontic levels. They are all happy with their respective objects. As for the Lord Śiva, He is supreme. . </p>

3020<p>As for the Lord Śiva, He is satisfied within all the beings. He is the body of the constituents of all the beings, for He is the Cause of everything that exists. That is what should be kept in mind by one who knows the scriptures.</p><p rend="stanza" n="71">All<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>cidvalli</ref></seg> the ontic levels exist [latently], then they are spread once more. . </p>
3025
.<p>All the ontic levels exist [latently] in the Lord Śiva. At last they come out from Him. What is the reason for this to happen? As they constitute the body of the Lord Śiva, the existence of all the ontic levels is constant.</p><p rend="stanza" n="72">[Śiva] would<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>cidvalli</ref></seg> contract the ontic levels once more. . </p>

3030 </p>

. </p>

3035

3040 <p>The Lord Rudra is thus: like a dancer<note>The word <foreign>parigәl</foreign> is not attested in <ptr target="bib:OJED"/>, but is found in Modern Balinese with the meaning of ‘dancer (male or female) (<foreign>rigel</foreign> = <foreign>higel</foreign> dance)’ (DBE s.v.).</note> who is adorned<note>I have corrected <foreign>inyāsakәn</foreign> to <foreign>hinyasakәn</foreign>, which is only attested in <ptr target="bib:OJED"/>\ (s.v. <foreign>hinyas</foreign>) as <foreign>hinyasan, iṅesan</foreign> ‘to adorn, embellish, make up’. 3075<head>The Secret Doctrine on Brahman, Chapter 4</head>
.<p rend="stanza" n="1">Earth undergoes dissolution into Water. Water enters into Fire. Fire dissolves into Wind. Wind enters into Space.

.<p>Earth dissolves into Water. Water dissolves into Fire. Fire dissolves into Wind. Wind dissolves into Space.</p><p rend="stanza" n="2">Space goes into the <foreign>manas</foreign>. This is what is called the elemental body, the manifestation of the Elemental seed-syllable. It is said to be the condition of the body.<note><foreign>Śarīraniṣṭha-</foreign> may be the equivalent of <foreign>śarīraniṣṭhā-</foreign>, m.c., where <foreign>niṣṭhā</foreign> means ‘state, con\-di\-tion’—cf. the gloss <foreign>makasthānaṅ śarīra</foreign>, ‘to use the body as a residence’ (<foreign>sthāna</foreign>: ‘place; abode, residence, home; state, condition’, OJED s.v.). 3080</p>
.

.<p>Space dissolves into the <foreign>manas</foreign>. Such are the six ontic levels. At that time, their activity is to use the body as a residence. .<p>There is the supreme station. It is the syllable <hi rend="caps">uṅ</hi>. It is not diminishing.<note>The expression <foreign>tar pakasurudan</foreign> glosses <foreign>acyutam</foreign> (‘imperishable’) in the verse; cf. 2.14, and fn. <ref>kasurudan1fn</ref>, p. \edpageref{kasurudan1}. Their explanation is as follows.</p><p rend="stanza" n="14">Having been heard carefully, they should also be retained in the mind <sic>manaḥ</sic>:<note>I deem <foreign>manaḥ</foreign> to be a corruption, although the commentator seems to have intentionally glossed both <foreign>manasi</foreign> and <foreign>manaḥ</foreign> as ‘in the mind’.</note> Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, Space, and <foreign>manas</foreign>.
.</p>

3120<p>The specific qualities of the reverend Eightfold Śiva will be taught by me. Hold them fast in your mind. Pay full attention! Thus are all the learned masters—they pay full attention in their minds. Here they are: Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, Space, and <foreign>manas</foreign>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="15">The one life-principle is the Threefold World indeed. The origin is from the succession of no other [than that]. Earth and Water are to be known as Bhūḥ. Fire and Wind have to be known as Bhuvaḥ.
.</p>
.
.<p>The Threefold World is taught by the learned masters as follows. Know the enumeration of the worlds! The Earth and the Water are united by the learned masters: that is what is called bhurloka. The Fire and the Wind, they are what is called <foreign>bhuvarloka</foreign>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="16">The Space and the <foreign>manas</foreign> are called <foreign>svarloka</foreign>. {\curlybl}The Seven Islands, the Ocean, and the Seven Great Mountains.{\curlybr}<note>The half-line cd appears to be contextually out of place here, and may be the result of an interpolation or copying mistake. 3125
.<p>The Space and the <foreign>manas</foreign>, they are what is called <foreign>svarloka</foreign>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="17">Thus is the Unevolved: it is subtle, as if there is nothing that can be fathomed.<note>Or, alternatively (against the exegesis), one could read <foreign>pada</foreign> b as <foreign>yathācintyan na vidyate</foreign>, ‘unfathomable, it is as if it does not exist’.</note> This entire universe, [consisting of] the movable and immovable beings, comes from that.

.<p><foreign>Yathā</foreign>—as if; <foreign>evaṁ</foreign>—thus is the Unevolved: its nature is subtle. Nothing can be fathomed in it indeed. The entire world comes from the Unevolved. 3130</p>

.<p>\sqbrl This process] could be illustrated<note>While <foreign>upodghātakna</foreign> is not found in <ptr target="bib:OJED"/>, it surely derives from Sanskrit <foreign>upodghāta</foreign>, the meaning of which in this context is ‘an example, opposite argument or illustration’.</note> differently, as follows: the water comes from the moonstone-jewel because of the union with the light of the moon. 3135<p><foreign>Tadvat</foreign>—Likewise is the Unevolved, extreme in her subtleness. When she unites<note>Here <foreign>saṅgama</foreign> could also imply sexual union (between the Unevolved/Māyā and the Spirit metaphorically imagined as female and male): cf. <ptr target="bib:OJED"/> s.v. (<foreign>m</foreign>)<foreign>asaṅgama</foreign>, ‘to have sexual intercourse; to have social intercourse, meet, be friends with’; <foreign>saṅgama</foreign>, ‘coming together, meeting [...] union, intercourse [...] sexual union’. By means of their going asunder,<note>Here <foreign>viparīta</foreign> appears to refer not to the ‘inverted’ order of devolution/absorption of the ontic levels, but rather to the ‘mixing’ (and consequent imbalance) of the Three Constituents, which causes the Unevolved to manifest the universe.</note> the Unevolved becomes the universe.
.</p>

.<p><foreign>Sattva</foreign>, \raj, and \tam: they are called the Three Constituents. The going asunder of the constituents, that is the cause for the world to be born from the Unevolved: [that] is the meaning of ‘going asunder’. If \satv\ is predominant, a human being comes into existence. If \tam\ is predominant, an animal comes into existence. Thus is the order.%<note>The last two clauses of the exegesis do not quite reflect the idea expressed in the verse and the first half of the commentary. This opens to the possibility that a different concept might have been conveyed by both, namely that of manifestation rather than non-manifestation. In order to achieve this meaning, one could suppose that <foreign>viparīta</foreign> was understood in the sense of ‘going asunder or in different directions’ or ‘wrong’ (compare the Old Javanese meanings of ‘wrong, perverse; unthinkable, impossible, clouded, obscured, confused, blinded’), i.e. somehow out of balance; that <foreign>abyaktako</foreign> in the verse was intended as a hybrid Sanskrit-Old Javanese form with adjectival a- prefix meaning ‘manifested’; and that the sequence -<foreign>t t</foreign>- in [<foreign>hetuniṅ</foreign>] <foreign>jagat tan</foreign> [<foreign>vәtu</foreign>] reflects a (mistaken) gemination, which could be emended to <foreign>jagat an</foreign>, resulting in the meaning of ‘the cause for the world to be born from the Unmanifest’.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="21">Error<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">4.21-22</ref></seg> is fivefold, the abilities<note>Here the doctrinal context would require °<foreign>aśaktayaḥ</foreign> (disabilities) instead of °<foreign>śaktayaḥ</foreign> (abilities); cf. the next fn. [Its deity is] four-faced, four-armed, maintainer of the four aeons.<note>Here and in dyads 4.32–47 (compare dyads 4.27–28 above) there is a general lack of agreement between the number of different words in the stanzas, as well as a mismatch between the singular of the stanza and the plural in the commentary. .<p>The deity who is there possesses the eight sovereign powers and the eight supernatural qualities.<note>Both the verse and the gloss seem idiosyncratic, as normally <foreign>aṣṭaiśvārya</foreign> is a synonym of <foreign>aṣṭaguṇa</foreign> (cf. .<p>Not affected by pleasure and pain, not affected by revulsion and<ptr target="nirananda"/> desire,<note>The<ptr target="niranandafn"/> gloss of <foreign>nirānandaḥ nirāhāraḥ</foreign> seems to be quite idiosyncratic. .<p>Their series is [as follows:] the reverend Indra dwells on the eastern peak. The reverend Agni dwells in the southeast. The reverend Yama dwells on the southern peak. The reverend Nir{\rd}ti dwells on the southwestern peak.</p><p rend="stanza" n="72">Baruṇa<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>lokapalacommentary</ref></seg> is in the west; the northwest is endowed with Vāyu. Soma being placed in the north, the northeast is endowed with Rudra.
.</p>
.
3305<p>The reverend Baruṇa is in the western peak. The reverend Bāyu dwells in the northwest. The reverend Soma is in the northern peak. The reverend Rudra dwells in the northeast. All of them are the dwelling-places of the reverend Rudra.</p><p rend="stanza" n="73">Mahendra<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>lokapalacommentary</ref></seg> is in the northeast and the east; one should undertake the Elemental mantra [there]. The mantra pertaining to the Constituents is said to be in the southeast and the south.
.</p>
.
.<p>Your course of action there is as follows. The Elemental mantra is in the northeast and the east: <hi rend="caps">oṁ aṁ namaḥ</hi>. The mantra pertaining to the Constituents is in the southeast and the south: <hi rend="caps">oṁ taṁ namaḥ</hi></p><p rend="stanza" n="74">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>lokapalacommentary</ref></seg> mantra of Viṣṇu is in the southwest and in the west. Having placed it in the northwest and in the north, one should undertake the mantra belonging to the Spirit.
.</p>
3310
.<p>The mantra of Viṣṇu is in the southwest and in the west: <hi rend="caps">oṁ saṁ namaḥ</hi>. The mantra related to the Spirit is in the northwest and in the north: <hi rend="caps">oṁ baṁ namaḥ</hi>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="75">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>lokapalacommentary</ref></seg> mantra of Brahmīśāna is in the middle, below, and above. They regard the limbs as tenfold, being threefold for each of them.
.</p>
.
.<p>The mantra of Brahmīśāna is in the middle as well as below and above: <hi rend="caps">oṁ iṁ namaḥ</hi>. Now, its limbs are three times in the middle, three times below, and three times above. All of them together are tenfold, according to the words of the learned master.<note>I have supplied <foreign>pintiga i madhya</foreign>, following the Sanskrit <foreign>sarveṣāṁ triguṇa-viduḥ</foreign>, and assuming that the mantra should be repeated three times for each direction. However, this scheme yields the result of nine whereas we need ten.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="76">Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, Space, <foreign>manas</foreign>, Subtle Elements, Self-Identity, Intellect, Unevolved, Spirit, Lord: know the totality of the ontic levels in the mind, supreme, tenfold.<note>Here <foreign>daśaguṇaṁ</foreign> (‘tenfold’) might convey the idea that, as in the preceding dyad, these ontic levels have to be known as being tenfold (in spite of the fact that they are actually twelve); alternatively, one could translate it as ‘ten times’, meaning that they should be mentally repeated ten times.</note>
3315</p>
.
.<p>Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, Space, <foreign>manas</foreign>, Subtle Elements, Self-Identity, Intellect, Unevolved, Spirit, Lord: these are all the ontic levels. They are supreme. They make the Lord tenfold.<note>I conjecturally emend <foreign>bhāra</foreign> (cf. OJED s.v. <foreign>bhāra</foreign> 2 ‘weight’) to <foreign>bhaṭāra</foreign>, even if the resulting meaning does not seem to be entirely satisfactory.</note> </p>
.
.<p>
3320
.<hi rend="italic">Thus [ends] the scripture entitled ‘The Storehouse of the Worlds’, Chapter 4.</hi>
.</p>

.<div>
3325
.<head>The Secret Doctrine on Brahman, Chapter 5</head>
.
.<p>As the Lord spoke thus, the best of sages asked again. His words were:</p><p rend="stanza" n="1">O<seg cert="low">[Sage]</seg> Lord! Lord God of Gods! [When one] passes away while being an embodied creature in the world, if one gives up the vital principle, should one undertake meditation on emptiness?
.</p>
3330
.<p><foreign>O Lord!</foreign> O You, endowed with the eight supernatural powers! <foreign>O Lord God of Gods!</foreign> O You, king of all Gods! My question to you is as follows: if the life-principle is given up by me while I am in the cycle of rebirth, and when the human being vanishes,<note><foreign>surud</foreign> (OJED s.v.: ‘to diminish, decrease, draw to a close; to retreat, fall back, recede, withdraw, ebb, vanish; to be dismissed, removed’) glosses <foreign>nivr̥ttaḥ</foreign>, which I have translated as ‘passes away’.</note> what should I do in those cases?</p><p rend="stanza" n="2">O Lord of Gods! Where do I see [the Lord]? Of what kind and how is [His] supreme magical power? Does He attain the state of bodilessness?<note>I interpret <foreign>nairātmya</foreign> as being intended not in the (Buddhist) sense of the state of having no Self or individual existence, i.e. unsubstantiality, but rather of bodilessness, for <foreign>ātman</foreign> is attested in Classical Sanskrit with the meaning of ‘body’. This seems clear in the light of both the context of the passage as well as the exegesis, which glosses it as <foreign>tan pāvak karikā sira</foreign>.</note> [Teach] me<note>I tentatively take <foreign>tvayā</foreign> (emended from <foreign>tvaya</foreign>), occurring both in the verse and in the <foreign>pratīka</foreign> quoted in the exegesis, to be the instrumental case of the second person pronoun, and assume that the verb (<foreign>vācyam</foreign>?) is understood: cf. the exegesis, <foreign>an maṅkana ta pavaraha bhaṭāra maṅke riṅ hulun</foreign> (compare the gloss of Sanskrit verbs with such Old Javanese forms as <foreign>varahakna</foreign> in 1.15–1.16, [<foreign>m</foreign>]<foreign>avarah</foreign> in 3.25 and 5.48, <foreign>varahaknaṅ</foreign> in 3.29 and 3.36, <foreign>pavarah</foreign>° in 5.52 and 8.32, <foreign>varahakna</foreign> in 5.3 and 11.2, <foreign>pavarah</foreign> in 9.7, <foreign>pavarahan</foreign> in 9.2, etc.). Alternatively, <foreign>pada</foreign> d (also quoted, in identical form, in the exegesis) may be a corruption (or conscious redaction) of <foreign>tattvaṁ kathaya me ’dhunā</foreign>, which I have not emended since the gloss <foreign>aparan tattvaniṅ avakta</foreign> responds to <foreign>tattvāṅgaṁ</foreign> (rendered by the commentator as an ‘inverted compound’).</note> [His] limbs as the ontic levels, right now!
.</p>
.
.
3335
.<p><foreign>O Lord of Gods</foreign>, where do I see you?<note>Or: ‘how could I see the Lord?’ (cf. OJED s.v. <foreign>ndi</foreign> 2); however, as the <foreign>ndi</foreign> here renders the Sanskrit <foreign>kvacit</foreign>, the translation of ‘where’ seems more appropriate.</note> <foreign>Of what kind</foreign>—what is your form? <foreign>How is [your] supreme magical power</foreign>—of what sort is your power? <foreign>Does He attain the state of bodilessness</foreign>? He is without body, [yet] it is seen that He has a body. <foreign>[Teach] me [His] limbs as the ontic levels, right now</foreign>! What are the ontic levels of your body? Explain to me such things, o Lord, right now!</p><p rend="stanza" n="3">Because your words are about to be manifested,<note>I have conjecturally emended the second half of this <foreign>pada</foreign> on the basis of the exegesis, and understood <foreign>bhāvyāt</foreign> as the ablative of <foreign>bhāvya</foreign> rather than a pseudo-imperative/benedictive form of <foreign>bhū</foreign>, as in <foreign>pada</foreign> c.</note> the moon (<foreign>dhūm\-ra\-bhā</foreign>)<note>I emend <foreign>dhūmrayā</foreign> to <foreign>dhūmrabhā</foreign>, ‘the one having the appearance of smoke’ (<foreign>dhūmra</foreign> = ‘smoke-coloured, smoky, dark coloured, grey’); cf. the exegesis.</note> arises in [my] body. May your compassion be manifested! Tell me about the state of extinction!
.</p>
.
.<p>The reason why such is the speech of the Lord [is that], when I perceive the words of the Lord, it is not a matter of doubt that they will cause pleasure, like the light of the moon. Teach me about the state of extinction. Teach me about the state of release. <foreign>Because your compassion is going to be manifested</foreign>. Because of the compassion of the Lord.</p><p rend="stanza" n="4">O best<seg cert="low">[Lord]</seg> of sages, my speech [about] what is earthly and what is non-earthly [should be listened] by you. This supreme state of isolation, empty, is the union [with the Lord] in the state of bodilessness.
3340</p>
.
.
.<p>There is the station called the ‘state of isolation’, the obtainment of bodilessness.</p><p rend="stanza" n="5">Earth<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.45-52</ref></seg> is fivefold,<note>Here <foreign>pañcamaś</foreign> seems to be used in the sense of <foreign>pañcadhā</foreign>: compare <foreign>pr̥thivī pañcadhā smr̥taḥ</foreign> in 3.45d.</note> solid, characterised by hardness. It is the beginning of the chief constituents of the body,<note>OJED tentatively glosses <foreign>aṅgapradhāna</foreign> as ‘‘chief part of the body’’, head?’, but in the present context the compound is likely to refer to the chief constituents or essential parts (<foreign>pradhāna</foreign>) of the human body. The TJñ (42) describes it as the combination of mind and body (<foreign>ambәk pva ṅaraniṅ pradhānatattva| ikaṅ ambәk lavan śarīra| yeka sinaṅguh aṅgapradhāna ṅaranya maṅke riṅ mānuṣa</foreign>); cf. also 45, 46, 50.</note> consisting of flesh, nerves, etc.
.</p>
3345
.
.<p>The qualities of the Earth are five: smell, taste, form, touch, and sound. Its existence is permanent.<note>The commentator understood the Sanskrit <foreign>sthira</foreign> in the sense of ‘permanent’, ‘lasting’ rather than ‘compact, solid, strong’, which I think was the original meaning in this context.</note> Its characteristic is hardness. It produces the chief constituents of the body: flesh, bones, muscles. That was their former state.</p><p rend="stanza" n="6">Then<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.45-52</ref></seg> there is Water, having four qualities,<note>I have conjecturally emended the sequence <foreign>tatra paścat guṇan</foreign> to <foreign>tataś caturguṇan</foreign>. It is the supreme embodiment of the life principle, auspicious.
.</p>
.
3350<p>The qualities of Water are taste, form, smell, touch. Its characteristics are to melt and to flow. Blood, urine, and sweat are the first of them [among the five existing in the body]. Its essential nature is the Holy Soul. It (i.e., water) serves as its embodiment. It is supreme.</p><p rend="stanza" n="7">One<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.45-52</ref></seg> knows the Brilliant (i.e., Fire) as having three qualities. It is hot, characterized by redness. It is accompanied by desire, anger, etc. It is the fire of the body, eminent.
.</p>
.
.<p>The qualities of Fire are three: form, touch, and sound.<note>I have supplied <foreign>sparśa</foreign> and <foreign>śabda</foreign> on the basis of the context.</note> Its qualities are fever<note>I interpret <foreign>panas tis</foreign> (‘heat and cold; all that may befall one; fever’, OJED s.v.) as ‘fever’, although <foreign>panas</foreign> ‘heat’ seems to aptly respond to <foreign>uṣṇa</foreign> in the verse.</note> and self-conceit. Desire and anger are their precursors. That is the fire of the body. It is eminent.</p><p rend="stanza" n="8">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.45-52</ref></seg> Wind is said to be twofold indeed, characterised by touch and sound. It is the breath, whose essence is the life-principle, eternal. It is the mind of all the embodied beings.
.</p>
3355
.<p>Such is the Wind, its qualities are two: touch and sound. It is shaky. Its characteristic is movement. Its essential nature is the life-principle. Its existence is permanent. It serves as the consciousness of the body.</p><p rend="stanza" n="9">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.45-52</ref></seg> Space has one quality. It is well established in the body. It is contained in the orifices of both ears,<note>My emendation of <foreign>vāyorodhyañ</foreign> to <foreign>’bhayor randhrañ</foreign> (both unmetrical; °<foreign>añ</foreign> for °<foreign>e</foreign>) is conjectural, and presupposes that <foreign>randhrañ</foreign> was understood as a locative, just like <foreign>nāsikādyaḥ</foreign> in <foreign>pada</foreign> d seems to have been). The exegesis mentions ‘all the orifices of your body’, passing over in silence the ears.</note> in the nostrils, etc.
.</p>
.
.<p>Such is the Space, its quality is one: sound. It is placed in all the orifices of your body. The orifices of your nose are the first among them.</p><p rend="stanza" n="10">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">3.45-52</ref>▷ <ref>ubhayatmakacomm</ref></seg> <foreign>manas</foreign> is double in essence,<note>Here I take <foreign>ubhaya</foreign> to mean ‘double’ rather than ‘both’, in reference to the activities of <foreign>saṅkalpa</foreign> and <foreign>vikalpa</foreign> (cf. exegesis on stanza 3.4). First the visible is meditated upon, then the invisible.<note>Here I take <foreign>sandhyate</foreign> to be equivalent to <foreign>saṁdhīyate</foreign> (√<foreign>saṁdhyai</foreign>), m.c.</note> Thus the mind disappears, [having become] supreme, beyond the senses, and empty.
3360</p>
.
.
.
.<p>The excellent [state] should be spoken about thus. The activities of the <foreign>manas</foreign> are two. It forms ideations for all the things. How is that? As follows: first, one meditates upon<note>Here the passive form <foreign>sinādhya</foreign>° (from Sanskrit <foreign>sādhya</foreign>/√<foreign>sādh</foreign>, ‘to realise, to be accomplished or fulfilled or brought about or effected or attained, to be effected or brought about’) is likely to reflect the <foreign>sandhyate</foreign> (√<foreign>saṁdhyai</foreign>) in the verse, both in the light of the context and of the following verse, which mentions <foreign>dhyāna</foreign>. The forms <foreign>sumādhya, sinādhya, panādhya</foreign> (from <foreign>sādhya</foreign>) are glossed by OJED as ‘to intend, strive after, desire’, which do not fit the context. Alternatively, one could emend it to <foreign>sinandhyā</foreign>°, which is however unattested in OJED.</note> the material [world]; in the end, one reflects upon the immaterial. All the connected organs<note>The word <foreign>sandhīndriya</foreign> is attested nowhere else in the corpus of Old Javanese texts known to me. The Five Gross Elements and the <foreign>manas</foreign>, they are the <foreign>connected organs</foreign>. In view of the fact that they are the causes %<note>Or: ‘instruments, means’.</note>
3365of the Organs, that is the reason why they are called <foreign>Subtle Organs</foreign>. Further, the <foreign>manas</foreign> is without conflicting thoughts towards all the objects when it is empty.</p><p rend="stanza" n="11">The Sense-Mind should meditate on the great void, Śiva, the imperishable state of isolation, [which] becomes visible by means of the Sense-Mind.<note>I have emended <foreign>manaḥ ākāśānāṁ bhūtam</foreign> to <foreign>manasā sakalaṁ bhūtaṁ</foreign> on account of the exegesis (<foreign>sinakalakәn deniṅ manah ya vәkasan</foreign>; compare the identical gloss of <foreign>teṣān tu sakalaṁ bhūtaṁ</foreign> in 5.14c). .</p>

3370<p>In this occasion, the learned master meditates upon the stage of the void. It is called ‘Śiva’; it is called the ‘state of isolation’, without end. In the end, it is turned into a visible form by the Sense-Mind. When he has finished to meditate upon the state of the void, his abode is the state of bodilessness, perpetually.</p><p rend="stanza" n="12">What will become of the superior mind that is appeased? [It will be] empty, extremely subtle. But [were it] not so because of exceeding sin, he should meditate on the void in visible form.
.</p>
.
.<p>The station of the void, its subtlety is extreme. Even though [the yogin’s mind] is free from disturbance,<note>Being positioned after <foreign>malilaṅ</foreign> (= <foreign>praśāntam</foreign> in the verse), <foreign>tovi</foreign> seems to have a concessive meaning here; thus, the clause would refer to the yogin’s mind (<foreign>cittam</foreign>).</note> this [supreme state] is not met even once due to the abundance of his sin. In this case, the learned master should meditate; its supreme [nature] should be made clearly visible.</p><p rend="stanza" n="13">Having seen the paramount [light]<note><foreign>Bhūyiṣṭha</foreign> means ‘most numerous or abundant or great or important, chief principal’; provided it is not a corruption for <foreign>jyotiś ca</foreign>, I take it to refer to the light within the heart (cf. the exegesis, and the next dyad). For a similar context, cf. dyads 1.23–24.</note> that exists within [the body], he should fix the \manasmind\ [on it].
.</p>
3375
.<p>If he meditates, the light that is within is seen by him. It is called <sic><foreign>rayasthāli</foreign></sic>.<note>The corrupted sequence <foreign>rayasthāli</foreign> could be a <foreign>pratīka</foreign> reflecting <foreign>bhūyiṣṭhaḥ</foreign> in <foreign>pada</foreign> a.</note> When it is seen, he should fix the Sense-Mind on it by way of his attention.</p><p rend="stanza" n="14">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>paramanu</ref></seg> atomic individual and the infinitesimal particle<note>I emend <foreign>manuś</foreign> to <foreign>aṇuś</foreign>, which has the disadvantage of resulting in the somewhat pleonastic expression <foreign>maṇuś ca paramāṇuś ca</foreign> (both <foreign>aṇu</foreign> and <foreign>paramāṇu</foreign> can mean either ‘atom’ and ‘soul’). [That light] acquires a visible form by way of them, having a splendour equal to ten million suns.

3380
.
.<p>The light is like gold that has been inflamed. Its splendour is equal to a thousand suns. That is turned into a visible form by all the <foreign>paramāṇu</foreign>s.</p><p rend="stanza" n="15">Having<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">5.15</ref></seg> cast the gaze inside the heart, what is made of <foreign>tamas</foreign><note>Or: ‘ignorance’.</note> is dissolved again. A divine light is in his own body,<note>In the light of the gloss <foreign>iṅ avak</foreign> found in the exegesis, I tentatively emend <foreign>anandeṣu</foreign> to <foreign>svadehe tu</foreign>; cf. the emendation <foreign>śūnyeṣu</foreign> to <foreign>śūnye tu</foreign> in the following verse.</note> eight fingers’ breadth inside the head.

3385<p>The <foreign>tamas</foreign> is in the heart.<note>Here <foreign>hana</foreign> seems to render <foreign>bhū</foreign> in the verse.</note> At last it is dissolved into the atoms. When this happens, it is together with the splendour of the divine light in the body. Eight fingers is its measure in the interior of the head.</p><p rend="stanza" n="16">In this way he may see the state of bodilessness, above, whose visible mark is the void.<note>Following the exegesis, I construe <foreign>lakṣaṇaṁ</foreign> with <foreign>śūnye tu</foreign> (emended from <foreign>śūnyeṣu</foreign>), as if it were a ‘split compound’.</note> It is the station perpetually immaterial, imperishable, endowed with Śiva [divided] into eight [forms].
.</p>

.<p>When this happens, the learned master sees the state of being bodiless, there in the light. Its form is [as follows]: the void is the characteristic of the reverend Eightfold Śiva. It goes higher and higher. There is the ‘immaterial station’. It is the station of the Absolute. Its clarity is extreme. There is no desire in it.</p><p rend="stanza" n="17">He will see the shining void—shining and pure in the entire body, shining even in the Space [in it]—through a Sense-Mind free from activity.
.</p>
3390
.<p>The likeness of the excellent station is as follows: at last, it is an immaculate void in the entire body. It is immaculate even in the Space [in it]. That is seen by him by means of his Sense-Mind, fixed without being busy towards other [objects].</p><p rend="stanza" n="18">[He will see that void] within all the [remaining] Elements—Earth, Water, Fire, and Wind, in the middle, above, and below, as well as in the ten cardinal and intermediate directions.

3395<p>The nature of that station is to go upwards and downwards in layers. It is visible through all the Five Gross Elements.<note>The commentator understood this verse to be about the supreme station rather than the elements, having rendered <foreign>pr̥thivyāptejabāyavaḥ</foreign> as a locative agreeing with <foreign>sarveṣu bhūteṣu</foreign> in the sense of ‘all the elements’ rather than ‘all the beings’.</note> Its form is within the Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, and Space, and in the cardinal and intermediate directions of space.</p><p rend="stanza" n="19">Wherever one observes attentively, [that supreme station] is obtained there. Having abandoned the Sense-Mind, he enters into that [station], pure and without any desires whatsoever
.</p>
.
.<p>If any of those loci<note><foreign>ṅkāna kabeh</foreign>, literally ‘there, all [of them]’, here renders the Sanskrit construction <foreign>yatra yatra ... tatra tatra</foreign>.</note> is looked at by him, a Sense-Mind that is extremely pure is obtained by him. [It] will never be affected by desire.</p><p rend="stanza" n="20">The proffering of the syllables <hi rend="caps">a</hi> etc. in the state of absorption produces the supreme station. After [the syllables] at the end and at the beginning are generated, he should impose the seed-syllables at once.
.</p>
3400
.
.<p>I shall speak to you, o Hero, as follows: absorption is the yoga of the syllable <hi rend="caps">a</hi>: <hi rend="caps">oṁ aṁ namaḥ</hi>. Absorption is the syllable <hi rend="caps">u</hi>: <hi rend="caps">oṁ uṁ namaḥ</hi>. The endless ordinance<note>The exact meaning of <foreign>anantavidhi</foreign> escapes me. The compound seems to respond to <foreign>antādi</foreign> in <foreign>pada</foreign> c, whose meaning was not grasped by the commentator.</note> is the yoga of the syllable <hi rend="caps">ma</hi>: <hi rend="caps">oṁ maṁ namaḥ</hi>. The uninterrupted absorption<note>It seems that the commentator linked <foreign>nirantara</foreign> (<foreign>ex em</foreign>.) to <foreign>samādheḥ</foreign> in the first <foreign>pāda</foreign> to construe the compound <foreign>nirantarasamādhi</foreign> in the exegesis.</note> is the yoga of the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>: <hi rend="caps">oṁ oṁ namaḥ</hi>. The Leader among Ascetics should impose them [onto the body].</p><p rend="stanza" n="21">Thereupon, the superior extinction, the supreme station of extinction, [arises]. It is said to be extinction of the deliberating activity of the <foreign>manas</foreign>, as well as the Ten Organs.
.</p>
.
3405<p>When, at last, there is the state of release, supreme in exceptional measure, the Leader among Yogins will obtain [it]. Suddenly, the Sense-Mind is extinguished; in such a state, the Sense-Mind disappears, and also its organs. [It] ceases to form concepts.</p><p rend="stanza" n="22">This [supreme station] is devoid of all the Sovereign Powers, pure, supremely spotless. It provides the Space for everything that exists, whether in the Earth or in the Water.<note>I have emended <foreign>pr̥thivīm vā salila vai</foreign> to <foreign>pr̥thivyām vā salile vai</foreign> on the basis of the exegesis and the following dyad. But I wonder whether the verse actually intended to refer to the existence of all the elements within the <foreign>ākāśa</foreign>, homologized to the supreme station.</note>
.</p>
.
.<p>When [the Sense-Mind] ceases to form concepts, it is pure. Its clarity is supreme. It is abandoned by the supernatural qualities of the state of Sovereignty. 3420<p>When he sees the pre-death omens of all the gods, he should enter into the void. The concept of the obtainment of release by way of God is quite alien to Javanese Śaivism, and may reflect a South Asian understanding. Alternatively, one could emend to <foreign>devaṁ</foreign>, which would yield the translation ‘the station of liberation, [which is] God’; however, corruptions from <foreign>aṁ</foreign> to <foreign>āt</foreign> rather than the other way around are hardly ever attested in \tutur s: cf. the change from <foreign>prāpyate nirmalāc chivāt</foreign> in KT VP 1.23 to <foreign>kalpyate nirmalaḥ śivaḥ</foreign> in JñS 19.5 (cf. Acri 2006: 120; 2011: 553–556), reflecting both the philological shift from ablative to nominative and the doctrinal shift from the obtainment of release through God’s agency to the homologization of release to God.</note> like a leaf scattered by the wind.<note>I am not clear about whether the image of the leaf scattered by the wind here has the same import as in dyad 3.19, where it occurs as part of the wider metaphor of the ficus producing sprouts and leaves from seeds.</note> In such a manner, dissolving in the body spontaneously, it becomes pure spontaneously.

The context of both passages strikes me as being quite similar, i.e. the obtainment of a state of supernatural prowess by the yogin in his own body just before stepping into final liberation. Alternatively, <foreign>svayam</foreign> may be understood as a local development of the concept of <foreign>sahaja</foreign> (‘congenital, innate, hereditary, original, natural, natural state or disposition’, etc.), which is used in some Tantric traditions, such as that of the Bauls from Bengal and the Nātha Yogins, in the sense of ‘spontaneous enlightenment’.</note> It is pure spontaneously.
