The blissful extinction is obtained by him.</p><p rend="stanza" n="48">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>rainbowbody</ref></seg> pacified<note>It seems to me that <foreign>praśāntaṁ</foreign>, meaning ‘tranquillized, calm, quiet, composed, indifferent; extinguished, ceased, allayed, removed, destroyed, dead’, refers to a specific state of extinction, as its gloss as <foreign>kanirbāṇan</foreign> in the exegesis would suggest, that occurs at the moment of yogic death, just prior to the attainment of release. For the image of the rainbow compared to the supreme state, when the body dissolves and becomes pure or transparent, cf. dyads 5.28–29; for the concepts of <foreign>sūryadīpa</foreign> and <foreign>śāntacandra</foreign>, standing for the mantras <foreign>aṁ</foreign> and <foreign>aḥ</foreign> occurring in descriptions of yogic death in the SHKA and SutSo <foreign>kakavin</foreign>, cf. Ensink 1974.</note> [state] is like a clear lamp, like a clear rainbow; it is manifold<note>My translation of <foreign>bahuṁ</foreign> as ‘manifold’ is based on Haryati Soebadio’s (1971: 219). I have emended <foreign>bāyuḥ</foreign> to <foreign>bahuṁ</foreign> in the light of three facts: the first syllable of <foreign>bāyuḥ</foreign> should be short in order to allow for a <foreign>ra-vipulā</foreign>; the word is not reflected in the exegesis, which looks suspicious since it would have been the subject of the verse (i.e. ‘by way of it, the breath [reaches] the state of extinction ...); and a parallel in JñS 21.2, where <foreign>bahuṁ</foreign> in <foreign>pāda</foreign> c is glossed in the exegesis as <foreign>akveh lvirnya</foreign>, ‘many are its forms’. cf. my fn. to the exegesis below.</note> and uninterrupted. By way of it, extinction [is obtained, consisting in] the conglomeration [and dissolution] of the elements.<note>‘Conglomeration of the elements’ renders <foreign>bhūtapiṇḍanaṁ</foreign>, being my emendation of <foreign>bhūtapiṇḍadā</foreign>. It would have been tempting to emend the latter form to <foreign>bhūtapiṇḍataḥ</foreign>—just as Haryati Soebadio did for <foreign>bhutapindadah</foreign> and <foreign>butapindanah</foreign> attested in the manuscripts of the JñS—, resulting in the translation of ‘extinction from the conglomerate of the elements [is obtained]’. However, that solution has not only the disadvantage of going against the exegetical portion of both texts, which seem to equate extinction with the process of conglomeration of the elements, but is also less appropriate in this context. For a discussion of the process that seems to be alluded to here in the context of both Old Javanese Śaiva scriptures and Modern Javanese mystical texts, cf. Acri 2019: 293–295.</note>
.</p>
.
.<p>The appearance of the state of extinction is like the flare of a bright lamp; its form is like a clear rainbow. That is the unification<note>OJED glosses <foreign>amiṇḍa</foreign>, <foreign>pamiṇḍa</foreign> as ‘to have or adopt the form of, manifest os. (as), incarnate os. (in), take on a visible form (as), become one with’. Here the word, reflecting (<foreign>bhūta</foreign>)<foreign>piṇḍaṇaṁ</foreign> in the verse, seems to denote as process of conglomeration or unification (and at the same time, visible manifestation), as well as dissolution, in the one pure light compared to the supreme goal of extinction.</note> of the Five Gross Elements, when their many forms manifest themselves.<note>More literally, ‘when there will be the coming of their many forms’ (<foreign>yan tәkāniṅ lvirnya makveh</foreign>). The word <foreign>lvirnya</foreign> is my emendation of <foreign>vighna</foreign>: it not only reflects <foreign>bahuṁ</foreign> in <foreign>pāda</foreign> c, but also has a parallel in JñS 21.2, which reads <foreign>akveh lvirnya</foreign> (cf. Appendix A, p. <ref>appendixa</ref>). If one retains <foreign>yan tәkāniṅ vighna makveh</foreign>, the ensuing translation ‘when many impediments come’ would amount to an exegetical elaboration on the verse, reflecting the idea that the obstacles come to the practitioner as he is about to reach release (cf. Acri 2017: 542–544).</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="49">As for this divine body, it is easy [to obtain]; easily he will proceed toward extinction. O Hero, this secret of existence,<note>I have emended <foreign>brāhmārahasyaṁ</foreign> to <foreign>janmarahasyaṁ</foreign> on the account of the exegesis, which glosses it as <foreign>karahasyaniṅ janma ikā</foreign>, as well as the parallels in JñS 19.2c and GPT 41.c.</note> the beginning, middle, and end of it, I shall now proclaim in its entirety to you, o great-souled one.
.</p>
3505
.<p>For generating a divine body is easy; the state of liberation is easy.<note>On <foreign>meman</foreign> (glossing <foreign>sulabhaṁ</foreign>) meaning ‘easy’, cf. Acri 2017: 303, fn. 184, and OJED s.v., gloss on SāSam 436.2: ‘‘without much significance &gt; easy’’, a shift from the common meaning ‘‘achieving nothing, without success, in vain, not worth the effort, of little value, without much force’’,’).</note> Those are obtained by the learned master. Such a gnosis, it is the secret of existence. I will tell you that in its beginning and middle, as well as its end. I [will] teach you completely, for it is supreme. Thus will be my speech to you, o Hero.</p><p rend="stanza" n="50">Since [the master] has drank the unequalled esoteric teaching, [the pupil should be] a believer, one who has subdued the senses, virtuous, not low-spirited, and devoted to the teacher at all times.
.</p>
.
.<p>The supreme esoteric teaching has been drunk by the learned master. That is the reason why the conduct of the pupil should be faith[ful]: he should follow the particular code of the teacher, and should never be tired of carrying out observances. That is devotion toward the teacher. Such is the behaviour of the pupil. He should not be disobedient toward the teacher. The teacher should not bestow [the teaching] upon a man who is without devotion toward the teacher.</p><p rend="stanza" n="51">[The esoteric teaching] is not to be given to one who is ignorant in the Vedas and the Śāśtras, who is selfish, unrestrained,<note>I interpret <foreign>ayama</foreign>, not recorded in Sanskrit dictionaries, as an adjective meaning ‘unrestrained’. cf. supra, p. <ref>ayama</ref>.</note> querulous, not carrying out observances, poor, of low birth, ignoring the rules,<note><foreign>apakrama</foreign><ptr target="apakrama"/> seems to be used here in the Old Javanese meaning ‘deviating from holy tradition, immoral, contrary to nature, ignoring the rules’ (probably related to Sanskrit <foreign>apakarma</foreign>: cf. OJED s.v.) rather than the Sanskrit meaning ‘going away, flight, retreat, not being in the regular order (a fault in poetry)’ (MW). That this is not a corruption is suggested by the fact that it also occurs in 11.39. cf. my discussion supra, p. <ref>apakramadiscussion</ref>, and the next fn., <ref>apakrama2</ref>.</note> or a slander.
3510</p>
.
.
.
.
3515<p>If the pupil is not knowledgeable in the sacred literature, he is not to be granted it by him. If the pupil is selfish and disrespectful toward the guru, he is not to be granted it by him. If the pupil is strongly intoxicated by palm wine and the state of drunkenness is constant, he is not to be granted it. If the pupil does not carry out the observances, he is not to be granted it. If the pupil is in a pitiable condition, he is not to be granted it. Further, if he is of low birth, he is not to be granted it. If the pupil disregards the rules,<note>I<ptr target="apakrama2"/> regard <foreign>niṣkrama</foreign> (unattested in OJED) as a legitimate Old Javanese form approaching in meaning the Old Javanese <foreign>apakrama</foreign>, which has a meaning akin to, or maybe even derived from, the Sanskrit <foreign>apakarma</foreign>. cf. supra, p. <ref>apakramadiscussion</ref>.</note> he is not to be granted it. If the pupil commits slander toward the guru, he is not to be granted it.</p><p rend="stanza" n="52">[The master] desires to bestow [the teaching] to [a pupil] who is obedient to the guru and respecting the religious duties, filled with devotion for the guru, whose goal is the worship of the guru’s feet,<note>Here <foreign>pādāya</foreign> is in the singular m.c.</note> truthful.
.</p>
.
.
.<p>To a pupil who is obedient to the guru,<note>Here (and in the Sanskrit verse as well), <foreign>guruśuśrūṣa</foreign> seems to be understood as an adjective referring to the pupil (i.e., equivalent to the Sanskrit <foreign>guruśuśrūṣu</foreign>) rather than a substantive meaning ‘obedience to one’s guru’ (cf. OJED s.v., and MW s.v. <foreign>guruśuśrūṣā</foreign>).</note> and who loves the secret code of duty [that is] the instruction of the guru, whose tranquil mind and great devotion have as goal the worship of the feet of the guru, a pupil who is always attending to the personal work of the guru, who loves to carry out religious austerities—to such a pupil the guru should be willing to teach the secret code of duty.</p><p rend="stanza" n="53">This<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>bhuvanasarira</ref></seg> teaching has been spoken by me, the supreme and auspicious secret doctrine about the world and the body. He who knows it will reach Śiva.
3520</p>
.
.<p>The doctrine that has been told by me is supreme and truly auspicious, being the secret [doctrine] of the world and the body. It should be known by the practitioner. He who knows about the doctrine, as it is called, surely reaches the station of the Lord, as taught by the reverend sage Bhārgava and the reverend {\rdc}ṣis, Siddhas, and Munis who all together study the sacred texts with the Lord.
.</p>
.
3525<p><hi rend="italic">Thus [ends] the scripture entitled ‘The Storehouse of the Worlds’, the Secret Doctrine on Brahman, Chapter 5.</hi>
.</p>

.<head><hi rend="italic">vi</hi>: The Scripture on the Siddhānta-Gnosis, Chapter 1</head>
3530

.<ab>\normalsize{<foreign><hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, Hail to the Mountain-Lord!</foreign></ab>
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><sic>...</sic></p>
3535
.<p>The cause of what is designated as being mature (<foreign>matuhā</foreign>)<note>Here and in dyad 6.3, <foreign>matuhā</foreign> is the Old Javanese counterpart of the Sanskrit <foreign>vr̥ddha</foreign>; both expressions could be translated as ‘old’ or ‘mature’—cf. Haryati Soebadio’s (1971: 257) translation of <foreign>matuha</foreign> in JñS 27.1 as ‘he will be mature’ (= <foreign>vr̥ddo syāt</foreign>). However, one should keep in mind that, as it is clear from the context of dyad 6.3, they also convey the meaning of ‘experienced, wise, learned’, so the author might have been consciously playing with the intrinsic polysemy of these words.</note> is: one should not be careless towards the scriptures of the Siddhānta, so that he is not sinful.<note>While no verse is found in the manuscripts, the exegesis apparently reflects the first three <foreign>pāda</foreign>s of the opening verse of JñS 27 (also captioned <foreign>jñānasiddhāntaṃ</foreign>, <foreign>prathamaḥ paṭalaḥ</foreign>): «<foreign>adhītya jñānasiddhāntaṁ taruṇo ’pi varānane| tena jñānena vr̥ddhaḥ syāt na śīlo na vayastapaḥ</foreign>||» <foreign>rasiki saṅ maṅaji saṅ hyaṅ siddhānta, matuha sira, yadyapi rare kunәn, apan tan vayah, tan śīla, tan tapa matuha</foreign>|| ‘<foreign>Having studied the Siddhānta-Gnosis, although young, o fair-faced one, one will be mature on account of that gnosis, (not of) good conduct, age, or asceticism</foreign>. He who studies the Holy Siddhānta, he is mature, even if he is only a child, for he is mature irrespective of age, good conduct or asceticism’. .</p>

.<p>And also, a deluded person, who does not possess the gnosis, who is without good conduct, who does not perform the donation of wealth, who is not of youth, who is not of austerity—do not think that he will not incur in sin!</p><p rend="stanza" n="3">By means of that gnosis, o Skanda, he is known to be more mature than the mature—not because of the long moustaches [and] hair, not because of birth as a person of white complexion.<note>This refers to a high social status, presumably brahmanic: brahmins were regarded as <foreign>sattva</foreign>-dominated, as opposed to <foreign>kṣatriya</foreign>s (<foreign>rajas</foreign>-dominated) and <foreign>śūdra</foreign>s (<foreign>tamas</foreign>-dominated).</note>
3540</p>
.
.<p>To sum up: the wise one, he is fully intent on the Siddhānta-Gnosis. He is truly mature, for he is mature because of his gnosis. Likewise, o my son reverend Kumāra, it is not one whose moustaches are long, not one who is surpassing others in age, not one whose hair are long, not one whose hair are shaved and gleaming, not a person whose birth is high who is designated as mature.</p><p rend="stanza" n="4">One may learn all the scriptures [and yet, if] he abandons the supreme gnosis, he will not find even [an inferior] gnosis; alas, he is beguiled by illusion.
.</p>

3545<p>There is a practitioner who studies all the scriptures. The Holy Supreme Siddhānta is abandoned by him. <foreign>He will not find even [an inferior] gnosis</foreign>, such a practitioner does not experience My gnosis.<note>The concessive meaning of <foreign>api</foreign>, which is likely to have been present in the verse, where two types of gnosis are mentioned (i.e., <foreign>jñānam uttamam</foreign> vs. <foreign>jñānam</foreign>), is not reflected in the gloss of this <foreign>pada</foreign>.</note> <foreign>Alas, he is beguiled by illusion</foreign>, for he is in the power of My beguilement.

Thus is the word of the Lord.
.

3550</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="6"><foreign>Here in this world, o Great Goddess</foreign>, if the great happiness is obtained by him during [his] time in this world. <foreign>In the afterworld he will attain Śiva­hood</foreign>: in the future, when he becomes united with the Lord Śiva indeed.
.
.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="7"><foreign>Thus these right [statements have been spoken].</foreign> This is the end of My teachings to you, o Goddess. If you wish to communicate the holy Siddhānta-Gnosis, [it should be to] one who will be able to follow the custom of the offering to the guru. <foreign>If [the disciple gives] one-fifth [of his] wealth</foreign>,<note>The<ptr target="pancapana"/> interpretation of <foreign>pañcapadadhanaṁ</foreign> in the sense of ‘one-fifth of [the disciple’s] wealth’ reflects the meaning of <foreign>pada</foreign> (‘a part, portion, division’, cf. 3560<head><hi rend="italic">vii</hi>: The Scripture on the Material Ritual for the Ash-Mantra, Chapter 2</head>

.<p>
.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="1"><foreign>The production, maintenance and dissolution of the external [reality]</foreign>: The holy dot, that I shall teach you, o Goddess, and also its deities—Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Īśvara.</p><p rend="stanza" n="2"><foreign>manas</foreign>, Intellect, and Self-Identity is called production. 3570
.<p>Their manifestation during maintenance is as follows: the reverend Śiva is the Intellect. The reverend Brahmā is the Self-Identity. The reverend Viṣṇu is the <foreign>manas</foreign>. Thus is how they look like during dissolution, [as] taught by the learned master.</p><p rend="stanza" n="5">The <hi rend="caps">u</hi> dissolves into the <hi rend="caps">a</hi>, the <hi rend="caps">a</hi> is dissolved into the <hi rend="caps">ma</hi>; the <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> is dissolved into the dot (<foreign>bindu</foreign>).<note>The sequence of <hi rend="caps">a</hi> and <hi rend="caps">u</hi> seems to be purposefully switched—cf. the exegesis and the parallels in GPT and JñS. This suggests that the fourth <foreign>pāda</foreign> of the verse, where the series would be completed by the dissolution of the dot into the resonance, might have dropped or was intentionally left out, since it is not reflected in the Old Javanese commentary either.</note>
3575</p>

.<p>Thus is the reality of the holy dot, [as it is] reabsorbed internally. The holy <hi rend="caps">u</hi> is dissolved into the holy <hi rend="caps">a</hi>. The holy <hi rend="caps">a</hi> is dissolved into the holy <hi rend="caps">ma</hi>. The holy <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> is dissolved into the dot. The method of the production-maintenance-dissolution is as follows: <hi rend="caps">uṁ aṁ maṁ</hi>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="6">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">7.6</ref></seg> syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is recognised as Rudra, and Umā as <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>; <hi rend="caps">u</hi> is <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>, Brahmā is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>. The intelligent one should mutter [the mantra] <hi rend="caps">svāhāpati</hi> (i.e., Agni/Fire).<note>I emend <foreign>svāhāpatni</foreign> (<ptr target="#La"/><ptr target="#Ba"/>)/<foreign>sāhāpatnī</foreign> (<ptr target="#Bb"/>) into <foreign>svāhāpati</foreign>, i.e. ‘‘lord or lover of Svāhā’’, N. of Agni’ (MW); Agni being mentioned in 7.8–9 (cf. exegesis to 9, stating that the <hi rend="italic">oṁ</hi> together with the \ttl{svāhā} stand for the fire), the verse seems to refer to the muttering of a mantra to Agni encapsulated by or likened to <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> and <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>. cf. the next fn., <ref>dampatifn</ref>.</note>

3580<p>The reality of the holy syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is as follows: if the reverend Rudra is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, the holy <hi rend="caps">u</hi> is Umā. If the reverend Brahmā is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, the holy syllable <hi rend="caps">u</hi> is <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>. That is called ‘man and wife’.<note><foreign>Dampatī</foreign><ptr target="dampatifn"/> (norm.; <foreign>daṁpati</foreign> mss.) responds to <foreign>svāhāpatī</foreign> in the verse. cf. OJED s.v.: ‘(Skt <foreign>dampati</foreign>, Wed., lord of the house; <foreign>dampatī</foreign>, “the two masters”, husband and wife) man and wife; a couple, pair; forming a pair, with his wife’. The commentator interpreted <foreign>svāhāpati</foreign> (or the corrupt <foreign>svāhāpatni</foreign>) in the verse as a <foreign>dvandva</foreign> meaning ‘<hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi> and [her] husband’.</note> It should be known by the learned masters.</p><p rend="stanza" n="7">This <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> should come first, then, having [proffered:] the mantra and carried out the cleansing, one should make the ash-fist, [uttering:] ‘May the human being become Śiva!’
.</p>
.
.<p>At the beginning, he realizes the god of the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>.<note>Or: <foreign>vruḥ pva sira riṅ ādideva</foreign>, ‘He knows the Supreme God that is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>’ (however, this construction would not reflect the <foreign>pūrvaṁ</foreign> in the verse, which seems to be glossed by <foreign>ādi</foreign>, as well as the <foreign>rumuhun</foreign> in the following clause).</note> Then his action should be the cleansing of the hands, along with its mantra. When he has finished doing so, he should perform the ash-fist, and the transformation into Śiva.</p><p rend="stanza" n="8">The <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is the eater of the offerings (i.e., Agni/fire), the fire-wood are the Brahma[mantra]-syllables, Umā is the flame, of great splendour, while the smoke is Rudra.
.</p>
3585
.<p>How is the ash processed by the learned master? As follows: the holy Brahmamantras stand for the wood. The holy syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> stands for the fire, which burns the wood. The Goddess Umā is the splendour of the fire. The Lord Rudra stands for the smoke.</p><p rend="stanza" n="9">All the seed-syllables [made by] the Brahma[mantra]-syllables, the fire, the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, ending with the <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>: one should offer<note>I take the gerund <foreign>āhutvā</foreign> to be governed by <foreign>vidyāt</foreign> in verse 7.10a.</note> those as oblations [until they are] reduced to ashes, day after day.
.</p>
.
.<p>The learned master knows about the performance of the holy ashes: that is why he worships the reverend Agni (i.e., the sacred fire). The seed-syllables stand for the holy Brahmamantras. Those are his means of worshiping the reverend Agni. The holy syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> together with the holy <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>, those stand for the fire. They are worshiped by the learned master. [They are] reduced to ashes by the reverend Fire [over] a long [period of] time. Those should be reduced to ashes by the learned master.</p><p rend="stanza" n="10">The ashes should be known as the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>. Viṣṇu is known as the water. Agni is known as Brahmā. Because he has known [thus, he will obtain] liberation, without doubt.
3590</p>
.
.<p>How is the form of the holy ashes? As follows: The sacred <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is the ashes. The reverend Viṣṇu is the water. The reverend Brahmā is the fire. His liberation is without any remainder whatsoever.</p><p rend="stanza" n="11">Brahmā is manifested as the palm. Viṣṇu is the fore part [of the hand]. Śiva should be known as all the fingers. He will eventually reach the abode that is the final liberation<note>I understand <foreign>muktāntaṁ</foreign> as being used in the sense of ‘final liberation’.</note>
.</p>
.
3595<p>Here is what should be known by he who desires [to obtain] the abode of the Lord: the reverend Brahmā is in the palm. He is visible there.<note>The commentator understands <foreign>karatalaṁ</foreign> as if it were a locative (<foreign>karatale</foreign>).</note> The reverend Viṣṇu is the fore part [of the hand]. The reverend Śiva is in all the fingers.<note>I have emended <foreign>pūrvvāṅguli</foreign> to <foreign>sarvāṅguli</foreign>, so as to reflect the Sanskrit. In this context, <foreign>pūrva</foreign> is likely to refer to a part of the hand (the fore part?) rather than the first finger (<foreign>pūrvāṅguli</foreign>); further, it is appropriate for Śiva—conceived of as having a fivefold manifestation as Sadāśiva—to be identified with the five fingers of the hand.</note> The knowledge of the practitioner about the reality of the holy ashes of Śiva, along with their emplacement [on the hand], is easy indeed.</p><p rend="stanza" n="12">Śiva is declared to be the ash, and the palm the altar. The fingers are known as the firewood. The lines<note>I emend <foreign>loka</foreign> to <foreign>rekhā</foreign> in the light of the exegesis.</note> are the <foreign>maṇḍala</foreign>.
.</p>
.
.
.<p>The holy ashes of Śiva should be known by the practitioner:<note>It appears that here the commentator took the sequence <foreign>śiva-bhasma</foreign> in the verse, where <foreign>śiva</foreign> may reflect a <foreign>prātipadika</foreign> for <foreign>śivo bhasma</foreign>, as a compound (compare the expression <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ śivabhasma</foreign> in dyads 11 and 13 and throguhout this chapter), whereas two separate words were probably intended; my translation reflects this original meaning. Alternatively, one may read <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ śiva bhasma kavruhana saṅ sādhaka</foreign>, and translate it as ‘The reverend Śiva should be be known by the practitioner as the ashes’, which however does not mirror the structure of the remainder of the gloss, which is more idyomatic to express this type of comparisons.</note> the altar is in the palm; the fingers are the firewood; the lines of the palm are the lotus-<foreign>maṇḍala</foreign>.</p><p rend="stanza" n="13">He should divide the head into five parts, and proffer the fivefold mantra. <hi rend="caps">sa</hi> is in the East, <hi rend="caps">ba</hi> in the South. The clever one should place the <hi rend="caps">ta</hi> in the West.
3600</p>
.
.<p>The holy ashes of Śiva should be divided into five parts by him, and the [ap\-pro\-pri\-ate] mantra should be uttered by him: <hi rend="caps">sa pūr</hi> (Sadyojāta-East), <hi rend="caps">ba da</hi> (Bāmadeva-South), <hi rend="caps">ta pa</hi> (Tatpuruṣa-West).
.
.
3605</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="14"><foreign>The abode of Aghora is in the North</foreign>. <hi rend="caps">a u</hi> (Aghora-North). <foreign>Īśāna is on the top</foreign>. [Its mantra is] <hi rend="caps">i</hi>, in the fontanel. <foreign>The face of Śiva is on the top of the <foreign>liṅga</foreign></foreign>. In the <foreign>liṅga</foreign> in the face, there is the Lord Śiva, and also on \arrowrightx
.the top.<note>The gloss of this <foreign>pada</foreign> seems highly idiosyncratic.</note> <foreign>The man should erect those which have been seen [in this manner]</foreign>.<note>I retain the reading <foreign>yad īkṣam</foreign> (<ptr target="#Bb"/>) against <foreign>yad dīkṣam</foreign> (<ptr target="#La"/><ptr target="#Ba"/>), because the present context seems to be meditation rather than initiation.</note> Those are the six limbs of the Lord Śiva. They should be erected at the top [of the head]. It is there that the deities of the main and intermediate directions of the compass should be erected by the practitioner. How do they look like? As follows:
.</p>
.
.<p rend="stanza" n="15">One should recognize Īśvara as the face in the East (<foreign>pūrvāsya</foreign>), Brahmā as the face of the South, Mahādeva [as the face that is] in the West, [and] the face of Viṣṇu [to be] in the North.
3610</p>
.
.
.<p>The reverend Īśvara is in the East.<note>The commentator seems to gloss the ‘corrupted’ version of the <foreign>pāda</foreign>, reading <foreign>pūrvva syād</foreign> instead of <foreign>pūrvāsyam</foreign>, which makes better sense here (mirroring <foreign>mukhaṁ</foreign> in <foreign>pada</foreign>s b and d) and also avoids the problem of the concomitant occurrence of <foreign>syād</foreign> and <foreign>vindyāt</foreign>.</note> Brahmā is in the South. Mahādeva is the face of the Lord of the West. The reverend Viṣṇu is the face of the Lord in the North. Thus are the emplacements of the deities of the main and intermediary directions. The practitioner should apply the ashes<note>Here <foreign>bhasmakәna</foreign> seems to have a different meaning than in dyad 7.9, where it was used in the sense of ‘should be reduced to ashes’. Both meanings are supported by OJED: cf. <foreign>bhasma</foreign> ‘ashes’ and ‘reduced to ash, destroyed’; <foreign>abhasma</foreign> ‘with (applying) <foreign>bhasma</foreign> (as a sect mark)’; <foreign>bhinasma</foreign> ‘to reduce to ashes, pulverize, crush, destroy completely’; <foreign>bhinasman</foreign> ‘to smear with <foreign>bhasma</foreign>’.</note> in this precise manner. As follows is another [manner to apply ashes]:</p><p rend="stanza" n="16">[He] should apply at all times that ash on the hump,<note>The appropriate meanings of <foreign>kakud</foreign> here could be either ‘a peak or summit, chief, head’, or ‘the hump’. The former (perhaps in the sense of ‘the top of the head’) seems preferable as it respects the descending order of the bodily emplacements; however, the exegesis glosses it as <foreign>punuk</foreign>, ‘hump, back’. Compare the half-verse 20.304ab <foreign>kakudantaṁ lalāṭādi nyased dehe yathākramam</foreign> in the <foreign>Viṣvaksenasaṁhitā</foreign>.</note> on the forehead, on the throat, on the arms, on the heart, on the breasts, on the belly, on the navel, on the buttocks, and on the feet.
.</p>
3615
.<p>Hump, forehead, throat, both arms, heart, both breasts, belly, navel, back, both feet: such are [the bodily parts] anointed with ashes by the practitioner. He applies the ashes everyday.</p><p rend="stanza" n="17">Everything is purified by ashes, even one who has fallen into an animal birth. Indeed, thanks to those [ashes], those continually [reborn as] grass and plants attain the purity of body.
.</p>
.
.<p>If the practitioner constantly employs ashes, that is the reason why his body will become pure by means of the holy ashes. Further, those who are born as animals, grass, trees, all of them are released by means of the holy ashes.</p><p rend="stanza" n="18">Having made use of them, all the gods, along with the Daityas, Asuras, and human beings, as well as the Siddhas and Cāraṇas along with their followers<note>I have emended <foreign>sasiddhacāraṇaṅ gatvā</foreign> to <foreign>sasiddhacāraṇagaṇāḥ</foreign> in the light of context and the gloss. First, <foreign>gatvā</foreign> lacks and object; although it could be translated intransitively as ‘having passed away’, this seems to be at odds with the divine and semi-divine beings mentioned in the verse. Second, the word <foreign>gaṇa</foreign> appears to be glossed by the expression <foreign>samūhaniṅ manūt</foreign> (<hi rend="italic">ex em</hi>.; <foreign>samūhaniṅ manuk</foreign> mss.) in the exegesis (cf. the next fn.). Third, the compound <foreign>siddhacāraṇagaṇa</foreign> is attested in BndPur (OJ) 16.10.</note> obtain release by means of the ashes.
3620</p>
.
.<p>Further, all the deities and the Daityas, the Dānavas and the human beings, along with the Siddhas and Cāraṇas in the first place, as well as the ensemble of the[ir] followers,<note>I have emended [<foreign>samūhaniṅ</foreign>] <foreign>manuk</foreign> to [<foreign>samūhaniṅ</foreign>] <foreign>manūt</foreign> (responding to the <foreign>gaṇāḥ</foreign> [<hi rend="italic">ex em</hi>.; <foreign>gatvā</foreign> mss.]\ in the verse), for <foreign>manuk</foreign> ‘birds’ does not seem to be contextually appropriate here, and a shift from <foreign>ū</foreign> to <foreign>u</foreign> and <foreign>t</foreign> to <foreign>k</foreign> is easy to justify on palaeographic grounds.</note> they are all liberated by means of those holy ashes of Śiva.</p><p rend="stanza" n="19">Those who carry out observances live on those ashes strenuously, carrying the topknot and the garment of tree-bark; they carry out meritorious acts at all times.
.</p>
.
3625<p>Thus is the divine quality of the holy ashes of Śiva. That is why the Leader among Yogins should be dedicated to carry out the observance of the holy ashes of Śiva.</p><p rend="stanza" n="20">The ashes are turned into a daily means of livelihood. [The yogin] endowed with devotion towards Śiva partakes of non-separation because of the conjunction between the river and the ocean.
.</p>
.
.<p>If the yogin continuously uses the holy ashes of Śiva as means of livelihood, he is united with Śiva, possessing the state of oneness with the Lord Śiva, like the union of the lightning and the ocean.<note>The gloss of <foreign>sarit</foreign> (‘river’) in the verse as <foreign>kilat</foreign> (‘lightning’) is idiosyncratic, and may reflect a confusion with the word <foreign>taḍit</foreign>, meaning ‘stroke, lightning’ (MW), combined with the commentator’s lack of familiarity with the stock image of the confluence of the river into the ocean (cf. the parallels in RauSS 8.10d, 13ab); note that the word <foreign>kilat</foreign> (probably glossing <foreign>tatkṣaṇam śūnyam ācaret</foreign>) occurs in 5.47, where it conveys the image of the yogin’s attainment of extinction like a lightening that disappears instantly.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="21">The syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is to be known as the Spirit, the <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi> is regarded as the Nature. The syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is called Viṣṇu, the <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi> is celebrated in the world as Śrī.
.</p>
3630
.<p>What is the reason why the learned master is united [with the Lord] by way of turning the holy ashes of Śiva as means of livelihood? As follows: the holy syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> is the Spirit, the holy <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi> is the Nature. The Lord Viṣṇu is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>; the Goddess Śrī is the <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>. She is famous in the world as being such. [These correspondences] should be known by the learned masters.</p><p rend="stanza" n="22">Likewise, Brahmā is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi> is Sāvitrī, [his] wife.
.</p>
.
.<p>If the reverend Brahmā is the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, Sāvitrī is the <hi rend="caps">svāhā</hi>. The reason why the holy ashes of Śiva are special is as follows:</p><p rend="stanza" n="23">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">7.23</ref></seg> Lord Viṣṇu is the <hi rend="caps">sa</hi>, the <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> is the Lord Śiva, the <hi rend="caps">bha</hi> is the Lord Brahmā. One reality becomes threefold.
3635</p>
.
.<p>Such is the reason why the holy ashes of Śiva are special. The reverend Tri\-sa\-ma\-ya<note>cf. OJED s.v.: ‘(‘‘the meeting of three’’?) name of the trinity Brahmā, Wiṣṇu, Śiwa’.</note> is in the ashes: the Lord Viṣṇu is the <hi rend="caps">sa</hi>, the Lord Śiva is the <hi rend="caps">ma</hi>, the Lord Brahmā is the <hi rend="caps">bha</hi>. Thus is their nature as the three become\ one.<note>The Sanskrit <foreign>cvi</foreign>-form <foreign>trayī-bhavet</foreign> (<foreign>trayi</foreign> mss.) is analyzed by the commentator as two separate words, <foreign>trayī</foreign> (subj., as if it were <foreign>trayaḥ</foreign>, ‘triad’) and <foreign>ekatattvaṁ</foreign> (obj.), resulting in an inverted sequence—i.e. three becoming one rather than one reality becoming threefold, as in the Sanskrit). Alternatively, <foreign>trayi</foreign> could be a corruption of <foreign>trayaṁ</foreign> (but the occurrence in 3.76d of the analogous construction <foreign>eko eva trayībhavet</foreign> makes this possibility less likely).</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="24">The syllable <hi rend="caps">bha</hi> creates the world.<note>In the light of the context as well as the commentary, I take <foreign>loke</foreign> in <foreign>pada</foreign>s a and b as an Aiśa use of the locative in lieu of the accusative. Compare the nominative <foreign>prajāḥ</foreign> instead of the accusative <foreign>prajāṇ</foreign> in <foreign>pada</foreign> b.</note> The <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> destroys the creatures. The <hi rend="caps">sa</hi> protects the world. They are one in nature [while being] individually distinct.
.</p>
.
3640<p>Thus are their manifestations: the <hi rend="caps">bha</hi> creates the world. The <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> destroys the beings. The <hi rend="caps">sa</hi> protects the world. Thus is the manifestation of the one being different.</p><p rend="stanza" n="25">Production is the Lord Brahmā, maintenance is Viṣṇu, dissolution is the Lord Rudra—the threefold refuge of the Three Worlds.
.</p>
.
.<p>The Lord Brahmā is production. The Lord Viṣṇu is maintenance. The Lord Rudra is dissolution. Thus are the three serving as the refuge of the worlds.</p><p rend="stanza" n="26">What are called production, maintenance, and dissolution are the abodes of the gods, beginning with Brahmā etc.<note>Here <foreign>śaraṇa</foreign> (in <foreign>suraśaraṇaḥ</foreign>) may not have been intended in the sense of ‘refuge, protection’ (unlike in the preceding verse), but rather of ‘habitation, abode’: thus, each one of the three gods abides in (i.e., embodies or superintends to) one of the three states.</note> May the knower of reality be without desire for the permanent and impermanent worlds.<note>The last <foreign>pāda</foreign> seems to be only loosely connected to the contents of the remainder of the verse. Further, one might emend <foreign>astu</foreign> to <foreign>asti</foreign>, on the basis of the exegesis.</note>
.</p>
3645
.<p>What is the appearance of the world? It resorts to the three.<note>I have translated <foreign>makaśaraṇa</foreign> as ‘to resort to’; cf. OJED (s.v. <foreign>śaraṇa</foreign>, <foreign>makaśaraṇa</foreign>), ‘to have as (or: to be) refuge or protection; to use as a means, resorting to, by means of’ (<foreign>śaraṇa</foreign>: ‘refuge, protection; also (cf. Mod[ern ]J[avanese]): help, aid, means’), but one could also more closely adhere to the Sanskrit meaning and translate ‘it has as abode the three’.</note> Thus are all the worlds, their forms are <foreign>nityānitya</foreign>: their natures are lasting and non-lasting. The production, maintenance, and dissolution: the reverend Brahmā is the first among them. That is why the knower of reality has no desire towards the world.</p><p rend="stanza" n="27">Brahmā is the creation of the world. Viṣṇu is the preserver. Rudra is the destroyer of the world,<note>The locative <foreign>loke</foreign> may have been used in lieu of the genitive.</note> [including] mankind as well as animate and inanimate beings.
.</p>
.
.<p>The reverend Brahmā creates the world. The reverend Viṣṇu protects the creatures. The Lord Rudra destroys the world. The mankind and the movable and immovable beings, they are destroyed by the reverend Rudra.</p><p rend="stanza" n="28">O Goddess, I am the extraction of the mantra, with the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> as the first [unit], paramount. O fair-faced one, know that at the top of [My] body is the <hi rend="caps">vaṣaṭ</hi>.
3650</p>
.
.<p>This mantra, o Goddess, is my body. And the mantra <hi rend="caps">vaṣaṭ</hi> is placed at the top. You should know that, o Goddess.</p><p rend="stanza" n="29">As long as a human being lives, o Goddess, [he should endeavour] to [obtain] a pure embodiment by means of ashes. Once he has left behind the body, he is released, [even after] a million of births.<note>I have conjecturally emended <foreign>pada</foreign> d on the basis of the exegesis.</note>
.</p>
.
3655
.<p>The meaning of becoming a human being is that, as long as one is alive, that is the reason why one’s body should be purified by means of the ashes. In the same way is the body when it is left behind by one’s own life principle, for the body is released at last, even if he were to undertake the continuous practice of the holy ashes of Śiva during millions of rebirths in order not to be affected by sin, which has as fruit the purity of his body.</p><p rend="stanza" n="30">Whether one is a male or even a hermaphrodite, a female, a foreigner, or a <foreign>śūdra</foreign>, because of having constantly known the ashes, o Goddess, he/she goes to Śiva after leaving [the body].
.</p>
.
.<p>Human beings who practice with the holy ashes of Śiva, whatever is their kind<note>This seems to be the meaning of the expression <foreign>adyapi sāvakanya</foreign>, in which <foreign>adyapi</foreign> = ‘although, even though, even if, even’, and <foreign>sāvakanya</foreign> = ‘whatever kind of’ (cf. OJED s.v. <foreign>avak</foreign>).</note>\newline—whether a male or an eunuch, whether a woman or a <foreign>śūdra</foreign> or a being of low status—all of them, o Goddess, if they know the holy ashes of Śiva in the right manner, when their body is abandoned by the holy life principle, they—the human beings who know the reality of the ashes—reach the station of Śiva.newline
3660\ \\</p>
.<p><foreign>Thus [ends] the Scripture on the Material Ritual for the \mbox{Ash-Mantra, Chapter 2.</foreign></p>
. </div>
. <div>
.<head>The Succinct Exposition of the Gnosis, Chapter 3</head>
3665
.<p>
.<foreign>God spoke</foreign>:
.
.The<seg cert="low">Lord</seg> discussion of the holy ashes of Śiva, which has been spoken about to you, o Goddess, is finished. Now I shall teach you another [topic:] the fruit of the daily cleansing.<note>Although there is no difference in the manuscripts, I normalize <foreign>śoca</foreign> to <foreign>śauca</foreign> in the verses, and retain <foreign>śoca</foreign> (attested as such in OJED) in the exegesis.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="1">O Goddess, the fruit of the cleansing with leaves, if [performed] everyday, is a thousand-fold; [that of] the cleansing with earth and water is a hundred thousand-fold and a million-fold [respectively].
3670</p>
.
.
.<p>The leaves used as a means for the cleansing, their fruit is a thousand, if [used] everyday. The earth used as a means for the cleansing, its fruit is one hundred thousand. The water used as a means for the cleansing, its fruit is a million.
.
3675
.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="2"><foreign>The cleansing with ashes will give a fruit, and that fruit is a thousand times ten millions</foreign>. The fruit of ashes being used as a means for the cleansing is as follows: its fruit is a thousand times ten millions. <foreign>The cleansing with gnosis, [its fruits are] unlimited</foreign>. There is a fifth [type] of cleansing: it is the cleansing with gnosis indeed, being superior to all the cleansings. Its fruits are unlimited. This would be my teaching to you, o Goddess.</p><p rend="stanza" n="3">The cleansing with leaves<note>I emend <foreign>pattraśaucānāṁ</foreign> to <foreign>pattraśaucāna\ṁm</foreign>, which I take to be the equivalent of <foreign>pattraśaucana\ṁm</foreign>, m.c. Alternatively, one could read (as it was perhaps originally intended) <foreign>pattra-śaucānāṁ</foreign> (in lieu of <foreign>pattraṁ śaucana\ṁm</foreign>, m.c.), meaning ‘Among the cleansings, the one with leaves’—cf. such similar expressions as <foreign>sarveṣām eva śaucānām| annaśaucaṁ paraṁ smr̥tam</foreign> in ViSm 22.89), etc.</note> is the lowest. The [one with] earth is middling. [Higher] than those two is the cleansing with water; [higher] than those three are the ashes for the cleansing, o Goddess.
.</p>
.
.
3680<p>The sequence is as follows: the leaves used as a means for the cleansing would be the lowest. The earth used as a means for the cleansing would be middling. The water used as means for the cleansing would be the highest, because it is superior to those two. The ashes used as means for the cleansing are superior to those three.</p><p rend="stanza" n="4">Gnosis is the highest [means of] cleansing among those, known as more secret than the secret. One whose mind is free from sorrow<note>I emend the sequence <foreign>divyāt vigatamānasaḥ</foreign> in <ptr target="#La"/><ptr target="#Bb"/> and <foreign>divyātvaṁ gatamānasaḥ</foreign> in <ptr target="#Ba"/> to <foreign>vidyāt viśokamanasaḥ</foreign> (<foreign>ś</foreign> and <foreign>t</foreign> are easily confused in Balinese script).</note> would know all this carefully.
.</p>
.
.<p>The leaves, earth, water, and ashes used as means of cleansing are lower than the cleansing through gnosis. Only the cleansing through gnosis is indeed the highest among them all, [more] secret than the secret. You should know that, o Goddess. Your manner to know that is that You should exert full attention towards that. Its goal, as it is known, is to bring the cycle of existence to an end.<note>This clause reflects neither <foreign>vidyāt viśokamanasaḥ</foreign> (<foreign>ex conj.</foreign>) nor the original readings in the manuscripts, although one should keep in mind the possibility of emending <foreign>vigatamānasaḥ</foreign> to <foreign>vigatasaṁsāre</foreign> (‘for the sake of the destruction of the cycle of existence’), which would however result in an unmetrical <foreign>pada</foreign>.</note> Thus were the words of the Lord to the Goddess.</p>
. <p rend="stanza" n="5">What<seg cert="low">Goddess</seg> is the seed-syllable of the ashes, when it is exoteric? Is the exoteric [form provided with] mantra or devoid of mantra?<note>This half-<foreign>śloka</foreign> is marred by metrical problems, and the extra syllables or words in both <foreign>pāda</foreign>s suggest that it may be a corrupted fragment of a complete <foreign>śloka</foreign>. While I am not confident enough to restore it, I can note that the clause <foreign>aparan ... sāmānya vīja rikā</foreign> in the exegesis reflects <foreign>pada</foreign>s a and b (<foreign>kim bhasmanaḥ vījaṁ yadā| sāmānya\ṁm</foreign>), while <foreign>āparan mantra ... tan pamantra kunәṅ</foreign> reflects <foreign>mantranirmantra</foreign>° in the second half-verse.</note>
3685</p>
.
.<p>The Goddess spoke: o Lord, with your permission, what is the form of the seed-syllable of the holy Ashes of Śiva, when the seed-syllable in it is exoteric? And, what is its mantra, if it is an exoteric mantra? Does it have a mantra,<note>I have emended <foreign>āparan mantra kari ya</foreign> to <foreign>apa samantra kari ya</foreign>, for here the intention of the author was apparently to introduce the question as to whether the seed-syllable has a mantra or not (<foreign>tan pamantra kunәṅ</foreign>)—thus, the <foreign>apa</foreign> responds to the <foreign>kiṁ</foreign> in the Sanskrit; <foreign>āparan</foreign>, glossed in OJED as ‘what/which/what sort of?’, would be pleonastic here: cf. line 2.</note> or is it without mantra? Thus [are my questions] about that [matter], with your permission. Thus were the words of the Goddess.
.<hi rend="italic">The God spoke</hi>, his words were [as follows]:</p><p rend="stanza" n="6">The <hi rend="caps">bha</hi> is the form of Brahmā, the <hi rend="caps">sa</hi> is Viṣṇu. The <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> is my very form. The <foreign>praṇava</foreign> is known as the three syllables.
.</p>
3690
.<p>The words of the Lord were as follows: The <hi rend="caps">bha</hi> is the form of the reverend Brahmā. The <hi rend="caps">sa</hi> is the form of the reverend Viṣṇu. The <hi rend="caps">ma</hi> is the form of Īśvara. You should know that those three are Myself, o Goddess.<note>Here the <foreign>praṇava</foreign> is not mentioned, but hinted at through the equivalence between its three constituents and the Lord.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="7">This <foreign>praṇava</foreign> that is [made of] ashes should be installed inside the body. [If] the material and immaterial ashes are known, there is no transmigration.
.</p>
.
.<p>Where are those that are called <foreign>ashes</foreign>? He should join them<note>The passive irrealis verbal form <foreign>sahajakna</foreign> responds to <foreign>niyujyatām</foreign> in the verse, and is therefore likely to derive from <foreign>sahaja</foreign> 2 ‘= <foreign>saha</foreign> (together with) and <foreign>sahaya</foreign>?’ (OJED s.v.), having a similar meaning to <foreign>sayojya</foreign>?</note> with the body. Those are the <foreign>material and immaterial ashes</foreign>. Now, he who knows about them, he is called a <foreign>liberated one</foreign>.<note>I take <foreign>mokti</foreign> (unattested in OJED) to be an orthographic variant of <foreign>mukti</foreign> ‘released, liberated’; compare the form <foreign>kamoktin</foreign> in <foreign>Bhuvana Pitu</foreign> 5b and <foreign>bhokta mokti vimukta</foreign> in <foreign>Rā\-ma\-pa\-rā\-śu\-vi\-ja\-ya</foreign> 20.2.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="8">The body of ashes is material. The body of gnosis is exceedingly immaterial.<note>Here I take <foreign>jñānadehātiniṣkalam</foreign> to be an Aiśa form for <foreign>jñānadeham atiniṣkalam</foreign>, m.c. An alternative translation, resulting from the reading of the line as <foreign>bhasma dehañ ca sakalam| jñāna-dehātiniṣkalam</foreign>, would be ‘The ash is the material body. The gnosis is the exceedingly immaterial body’.</note> The one endowed with the gnosis is released because of the unity with the formless gnosis.<note>I take <foreign>nirākāram| jñānekatvam</foreign> to be an Aiśa multipurpose ending for <foreign>nirākārāt| jñānaikatvāt</foreign>: cf. supra, p. <ref>multipurpose</ref>.</note>
3695</p>
.
.
.<p>As follows are the <foreign>material ashes</foreign>: the body is the material ashes. The gnosis is the <foreign>immaterial ashes</foreign>.<note>In the first line, the commentator construes <foreign>bhasma</foreign> with <foreign>sakalam</foreign> and <foreign>atiniṣkalam</foreign>, as if <foreign>pada</foreign> b read <foreign>jñāna-bhasmātiniṣkalam</foreign>.</note> Further, what is the gnosis higher than the gnosis? He who knows about the ash-gnosis, he is released by way of the supreme gnosis.</p><p rend="stanza" n="9">He who carries out all sorts of actions, good and bad, and who knows everything about the ‘Compendium on the Ashes’, [achieves] even liberation, which is difficult to obtain.
.</p>
3700
.<p> That is the reason of the behaviour of he who knows the summary of the holy ashes.<note>The gloss of <foreign>bhasmasaṅhārake</foreign> ... <foreign>jñātvā</foreign> as <foreign>saṅ vruh ri saṅkṣepanira saṅ hyaṅ bhasma</foreign> suggests to me that the commentator regarded the Old Javanese <foreign>saṅkṣepa</foreign> (‘summary, [main] contents; in short’, OJED s.v.) as a synonym of the Sanskrit <foreign>saṅhāra</foreign> (the <foreign>ka</foreign> in °<foreign>saṅhārake</foreign> being probably a mere expletive), among which meanings is ‘abridgment, comprehensive description, a compendium, manual’ (MW s.v. <foreign>saṃhāra</foreign>); thus, <foreign>bhasmasaṅhāraka</foreign> would be a reference to <foreign>Jñānasaṅkṣepa</foreign>, the title of this chapter.</note> He is not discriminating with regard to his actions. Good and bad are carried out by him indeed, for the state of release is difficult to be obtained by way of them.<note>I take <foreign>denira</foreign> to refer to the actions (either, implicitly, the good ones, or both good and bad?) rather than meaning ‘by him’, for the point of the verse is that the yogin may actually obtain release through gnosis and not actions. Of course, it is also possible that the commentator misunderstood the verse.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="10">This gnosis, o Great Goddess, is superior to all the ontic levels. It is also secret and difficult to achieve, bestowing heaven as well as release.
.</p>
.
.<p>The gnosis, o Goddess, is the highest among all the ontic levels. Further, it is difficult to be obtained. It is the cause of heaven and liberation.</p><p rend="stanza" n="11">He should bestow [this gnosis] against payment of one-fifth [of the disciple’s wealth],<note>cf. supra, fn. <ref>pancapana</ref> on dyad 6.8.</note> but not to a disciple who is not of service. Still, it should be bestowed upon a disciple who is peaceful and restrained, according to the rule.
3705</p>
.
.
.<p>Thus is the excellence of the holy gnosis, o Goddess. That is why you should not teach it to other people, or to a disciple who is not of service. How is the nature of a disciple who may be instructed in the gnosis? He is virtuous, his appearance and acts are good. In this case, the excellent gnosis should be given, together with the performance of prescribed ceremonies and offerings, etc.</p><p rend="stanza" n="12">The wise one should arrange open halls;<note>Here <foreign>vidhānet</foreign> could be an Aiśa optative constructed out of the noun <foreign>vidhāna</foreign>, which thereby functions as a verbal root.</note> having entered, he should instruct [the pupil about] the group of three: Spirit, the Lord, and [that which is] characterised by the Constituents (i.e. Nature) indeed.
.</p>
3710
.<p>How is the body of the gnosis? It is to be revealed as follows: the ‘Group of Three’ (<foreign>trigaṇa</foreign>) along with Tatpuruṣa and Īśāna. ‘The Group of Three’ means Sadyo[jāta], Bāma[deva], Aghora. As for Tatpuruṣa, [He is the] dot, [while] Īśāna [is] the resonance.<note>The commentator interpreted the verse, i.e. an enumeration of the three ontic levels from Nature to the Lord as homologues of the three constituents of the <hi rend="italic">oṁ</hi>, in order to make it fit within the fivefold mantric framework of the <foreign>pañcabrahmamantra</foreign>s and the audible/visible and inaudible/invisible components of the <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi>, forming the body of the Lord. This was done by taking <foreign>puruṣa</foreign> for Tatpuruṣa and <foreign>trigaṇa</foreign> (which could have possibly be <foreign>triguṇa</foreign> in origin; but for <foreign>trigaṇa</foreign> = <foreign>triguṇa</foreign>, cf. 2.2 and 4.28) for Sadyojāta, Bāmadeva, and Aghora, while passing over in silence <foreign>guṇalakṣaṇam</foreign>.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="13">The <foreign>praṇava</foreign> is said to be ‘lumped together’ (<foreign>piṇḍitam</foreign>),<note>The<ptr target="pinditatransl"/> term <foreign>piṇḍa</foreign> ‘lumped together’ denotes the aggregation of something. It is glossed in the exegesis as <foreign>patәmunikā</foreign>, ‘their coming together’ (i.e. the five constituents imagined as mantric limbs or faces of the Lord). The term <foreign>piṇḍa</foreign> found in Tantric texts usually refers to one-syllable mantras, to <foreign>bījamantra</foreign>s (<foreign>piṇḍamantra</foreign>), or also to the ‘body’—the last meaning being attested in the Nātha and Kubjikāmata traditions, and also in the Vaiṣṇava Pāñcarātrika JĀS (cf. TĀK III s.v. <foreign>piṇḍa</foreign>, <foreign>piṇḍamantra</foreign>). While the general meaning of ‘lumped together’ does make sense here, the meanings attested in Sanskrit sources seem to be equally apposite: the former would imply that the <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> has been reduced to a single entity/<foreign>bījamantra</foreign> out of its distinct constituents (yet it is still ‘adorned’ or provided with the dot and the resonance), while the latter that the <foreign>oṁ</foreign>} (= gnosis) is conceived as the (mantric) body of the Lord, whose constituents have just been enumerated in dyad 8.12; cf. <foreign>avaknikaṅ jñāna</foreign>, ‘the body of the gnosis’, and also the <foreign>praṇava</foreign> being ‘adorned with’ (<foreign>bhūṣitam</foreign>)—as if it were a body—the dot and the resonance.</note> adorned with the dot and the resonance. He who knows thus is not born again. Thus [he] instantly [obtains the state] that transcends the letters.<note>cf. OJED s.v. <foreign>nirakṣara</foreign>: ‘the state of having transcended the sacred syllables, end of a progressive simplification (<foreign>daśākṣara</foreign>, <foreign>pañcākṣara</foreign>, <foreign>tri tinuṅgalakĕn rwa bhineda</foreign>) in obtaining union with the deity (cf. <foreign>adwaya</foreign>, <foreign>śūnya</foreign>)’.</note>
.</p>
.
.<p>The coming together of them all is regarded as the syllable <hi rend="caps">oṁ</hi> (<foreign>praṇavākṣara</foreign>). It contains the dot and the resonance. That should be known by the great master. If he knows about that, he does not come back to be born again. He does not incarnate and is not perceived in a material form by any sort of created beings.
3715
.
.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="14"><foreign>This very [<foreign>praṇava</foreign>] is the material gnosis</foreign>. It is the cause of the obtainment of release. <foreign>The coming of death does not grant release.</foreign> When one does not know the coming of death, that is not release. <foreign>Listen, together with the six-faced one</foreign>! You should listen to my teaching to you, o Goddess, along with Kumāra.</p><p rend="stanza" n="8">O<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">10.8-9</ref></seg> Goddess, in a field, a forest, the bank of a river, a cave, a mountain, the root of a tree, a slab of rock, the knower of yoga gives up the vital breath.
.</p>
.
.<p>Where will the death of the knower of the secret means occur? [Such is] your question, o Goddess. Here it is: in a rice field, in a forest, the bank of a river, in a cave, on a mountain, in the root of a tree there [on that mountain], and on a slab of rock. There he will give up his life.</p><p rend="stanza" n="9">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref type="page">10.8-9</ref></seg> knower of yoga gives up the vital breath in a penance-grove, a forest, a house, a deserted mountain, a cave, an open ground, or an island.
3955</p>
.
.<p>Other [places where] his death will occur are the following: in a penance-grove, in a forest, in a house, in a cave, in a mountain, on an island, or in an open field—it is there that he gives up his life. If he dies there, he goes back to the Lord Paramaśiva.

.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="30"><foreign>Why<seg cert="low">Goddess</seg> is this form of Sadārudra called Kāla indeed</foreign>? 4010
.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="32">And similarly, his abode are the pupils of the eyes. If his (i.e., the yogin’s) face is pale, or if the sight of their respective [directions] is mixed together,<note>This expression might be a reference to a crossed sight, i.e. strabismus.</note> or if they are not full, or again if the distinction of [the pupils from the white of] his eyes is not clearly visible, if so, surely death will strike.

.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="33"><foreign>The learned one knows thus</foreign>. The yogin should know thus. <foreign>The ascetic makes an assertion</foreign>. This manner of recognizing<note>The Old Javanese instrumental form <foreign>paṅavruh</foreign> is glossed by <ptr target="bib:OJED"/>\ as ‘1. knowledge; 2. skill; 3. the way or the qualities by which one can recognize so. or st.’; in the last meaning ‘it is almost always in the arealis’, such as in the present instance. Here it glosses the Sanskrit <foreign>pratijñām</foreign>, which in this context means ‘statement, assertion, declaration, affirmation’, although the verbal stem <foreign>pratijñā</foreign> can also mean ‘to perceive, notice, learn, become aware of’. The commentator seems to have understood it in the latter sense. Compare the expression <foreign>denirān kumavruhi</foreign>, understood as a synonym of <foreign>paṅavruh</foreign>[<foreign>a</foreign>], attested at the end of the exegetical portion.</note> should be done by the practitioner: ‘<foreign>O Soul, go to the Supreme</foreign>!’ If so, the holy Soul will clearly depart towards the Supreme Station. Here is another [announcement]: ‘<foreign>The emptiness of the bodies is attained</foreign>!’<note>Or: ‘is perceived’ (taking <foreign>yate</foreign> to be an Aiśa form for <foreign>īyate</foreign>, m.c.); either meanings are not quite reflected by the form <foreign>maṅalivati</foreign> (‘to pass by, pass over, omit, overcome’; OJED s.v.) in the gloss. Perhaps one should rather translate it as ‘excellent’ (as a predicate of <foreign>śūnyaniṅ śarīra</foreign>), in the light of the form <foreign>amalivat</foreign> ‘to a high degree’ (OJED s.v.) and Modern Balinese <foreign>ngaliwat</foreign>, ‘pass, draw past, excel, surpass’.</note> Certainly [he] crosses over into the emptiness of the body if his manner of recognising is thus. This is dying whose origin is not suffering.

4015</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="34"><foreign>The everlasting Self is seen</foreign> [<foreign>as</foreign>] <foreign>a light on mirrors</foreign>. What is the yogin’s manner of seeing his own Self?<note>Although the preceding dyad suggests that the context is that of the body of the yogin becoming empty (i.e. invisible/transparent?), I have translated <foreign>avaknira</foreign> as ‘his own Self’ instead of ‘his own body’, which more accurately reflects the Sanskrit <foreign>ātmā</foreign>.</note> He should be like a mirror at all time.<note>The exegesis drifts away from the meaning originally conveyed by the analogy of the single sun (universal Self) reflected on multiple mirrors (individual Souls).</note> <foreign>Having perceived thus, o Goddess</foreign>. Such is the yogin’s manner of seeing his own Self. When it is seen by him, <foreign>He abandons the vital breath in that instant</foreign>. His life should be abandoned in the time[span] of an instant.<note>The use of the enclitic personal pronoun -<foreign>nira</foreign> after <foreign>kṣaṇa</foreign> seems odd, although it may render the <foreign>tat</foreign> in the Sanskrit <foreign>tatkṣaṇāt</foreign>, which is my emendation of <foreign>lakṣaṇaṁ</foreign>. When the yogin dies in such a way, [his] direction is not mistaken as he goes to Me. <foreign>He is like the ocean in relation to the rivers</foreign>. Here is his simile, among others: like the water of the rivers as it meets the ocean, the yogin and Myself are likewise. Here is another [simile]: <foreign>The rain is first in the cloud,<note>I take <foreign>himani</foreign> as an Aiśa declension of <foreign>hima</foreign>, as it were an -<foreign>an</foreign> consonantal stem. Among the meanings of the neutre <foreign>a</foreign>-stem <foreign>hima</foreign> are ‘frost, hoar-frost, snow, ice’, which are not entirely apposite here. The Old Javanese loanword <foreign>hima</foreign> has the additional meanings of ‘mist, low cloud’, and the latter is supported by the exegesis, which glosses the word as <foreign>megha</foreign>. Similarly, <foreign>hima</foreign> in high Balinese means ‘cloud’ (DBE s.v.). It appears that this word underwent a semantic shift in Old Javanese and Balinese, arguably as a consequence of the local tropical climatic conditions.</note> then reaches the ocean</foreign>. \arrowrightx
.Like a cloud filled with water: in the beginning, the rain falls on the sea. The salty[ness] is met with by it. In the same manner is the yogin with respect to my body, o Goddess.

4020
.

Verse 8.13 of the same text also contain a (con)textual parallel with <foreign>pāda</foreign> d, and the entire dyad indeed (cf. supra, dyad 7.20). I wonder whether a version of the text containing the word <foreign>bhinna</foreign> (not in the sense of ‘after death’, like in <foreign>bhinne dehe</foreign>, but of ‘distinct, different from’) was used by the commentator to gloss this passage.</note> Thus is his nature. When it possesses the Power of the Lord, <foreign>By virtue of the absorption of a river in the ocean</foreign>, [it is] like the action of the water of the rivers meeting with the sea. <foreign>Thereafter, he reaches Me, in a state of unity</foreign>. In the end, his body is one: thus is the yogin with Me.

4025</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="37"><foreign>O Goddess</foreign>, [<foreign>he who</foreign>] <foreign>knows the scripture</foreign>. Thus is the nature of the scripture, which you should know, o Goddess. <foreign>Characterized by union with happiness</foreign>. Its characteristic quality is the obtainment of happiness. <foreign>Even though it has been made secret by God</foreign>.<note>The expression <foreign>gopitenaiva devena</foreign> might be an ‘instrumental absolute’ construction, emphasizing the concessive nuance (see Aalto 1980: 45–46).</note> That speech that has been made secret by the Lord, <foreign>I shall reveal it to you fully</foreign>.<note>I emend <foreign>samān</foreign> to <foreign>samāt</foreign>, which I take as an indeclinable adverbial form of <foreign>sama</foreign>, ‘full, complete, whole, entire’ (\mwl). .<p>Thus were the words of the Lord to the Goddess. <foreign>The Goddess spoke</foreign>:<note>Since the Goddess, who addresses the Lord in the next five dyads, is not introduced, I have supplied <foreign>devī uvāca</foreign> (<foreign>sic</foreign>); compare the similar clause introducing dyad 10.1.</note>
4045
.</p><p type="ledinnernote" n="1"><foreign>I listen<seg cert="low">Goddess</seg> to your speech</foreign> [<foreign>about</foreign>] <foreign>the material and immaterial gnosis</foreign>. Note that °<foreign>nihitaṁ</foreign> here might perhaps be understood in the sense of °<foreign>hitaṁ</foreign> ‘beneficial, advantageous’.</note> The goal of your words is the happiness of the practitioner. <foreign>Here and in the other world</foreign>. Here and now, as well as in the future.
.

.<p>If the pupil is obedient, constantly devoted, in that [case] the holy Śai\-va\-sid\-dhān\-ta-gnosis should be taught by the learned master.</p><p rend="stanza" n="36">Not stealing, speaking the truth, devoted towards God, constantly studying:<note>On the basis of the commentary, I translate the four attributes of the clever one as <foreign>bahuvrīhi</foreign>s referred to <foreign>vicakṣaṇah</foreign>, in spite of the gender (or case) disagreement of the first two.</note> the clever one knows this Siddhānta-Gnosis, o Goddess.

4150
.<p>The way of acting of the clever one—the likeness of the one who can be given [the holy gnosis is as follows]: a man who does not steal, a man who speaks the truth, a man who is devoted to God, a man who does not mock the scriptures.</p><p rend="stanza" n="37">At no time [the gnosis] should be given to the son who is ignorant, to the pupil who lacks wealth, [or to one] who constantly reproaches the teacher.

.<p>How does one who should not be given the holy Śaivasiddhānta-Gnosis look like? 4155</p>

.<p>The men who should not be given the scriptures are: a man who steals, a man who speaks untruthfully, a man who is not devoted to the gods, a man who mocks the holy scriptures.</p><p rend="stanza" n="39">One who is impure, one who does not follow the observances and religious austerities, one who is ill-behaved, and contrary to nature.<note>On <foreign>apakrama</foreign>, cf. fns. <ref>apakrama</ref> and <ref>apakrama2</ref> on dyad 5.51; Introduction, p. <ref>apakramadiscussion</ref>.</note>

4160<p>A man who is addicted to eating everything that is impure, a man who does not desire [to perform] religious austerities, a man who dislikes observances, a man who is vicious, a man who dislikes the proper behaviour.
.The appearance of one laughing at the holy scriptures of the Śaivasiddhānta is as follows—his ignorance is paramount:</p><p rend="stanza" n="40">The artifice [of such a non-believer] is [to ask] a question first, with the intent of contention; desirous of asking, [he makes] a speech, [where\-in] the Tantra of God is reviled.
.</p>
.
.<p>Further, the artifice of one who dislikes the doctrine is to ask before, [then] to utter a speech for the second time, and finally to utter a dispute, as the Tantras of God were criticized out of his lack of any recollection at all. In short, he who mocks the holy scriptures of the Siddhānta, is condescending toward<note>This is my tentative translation of <foreign>manirakәn</foreign> (<foreign>manīrakәn</foreign> in <ptr target="#La"/>), which OJED glosses as ‘to set at naught, put aside, discard?’ cf. the next dyad.</note> he who is practised in the holy Siddhānta-Gnosis.</p>
4165 <p rend="stanza" n="41"><foreign>[If] his manner [of acting] is impure, give the secret doctrine to another one.</foreign><note>In order to obtain a translation that is consistent with the contextual logic of the passage as reflected by the exegesis and the surrounding dyads, I interpret ’<foreign>śaucaparyāyaḥ</foreign> as if it were a dative (cf. the two nominatives in t11.42ab), and as being the elided form <foreign>aśaucaparyāyaḥ</foreign>, wherein the <foreign>alpha privans</foreign> has dropped to avoid hiatus; further, taking into account the <foreign>kiṁ punaḥ</foreign> in the next verse, I emend the final <foreign>ca</foreign> to <foreign>na</foreign>. .
.</p>

.<p>For if the man who has already held fast to the holy Śaivasiddhānta is unsettled by another, and the words of an opponent criticising the holy scripture are followed by him, that is called <foreign>impurity derived from another</foreign>.<note>In order to arrive at this translation, I have emended <foreign>paraśoca</foreign> (literally meaning ‘purification for/from another’?) to <foreign>parāśauca</foreign> (i.e., <foreign>para</foreign> + <foreign>aśauca</foreign>). The commentary drifts away from what would seem to be the natural meaning of the Sanskrit half-line, construing <foreign>parasmai</foreign> with <foreign>śaucaparyāyaḥ</foreign> (as if <foreign>parasmai</foreign> was an ablative).</note> Therefore, one devoted to the holy Siddhānta-Gnosis is exclusively a pupil whose conduct is proper.</p><p rend="stanza" n="42"><foreign>Not to mention one who carries white</foreign> [<foreign>clothes but</foreign>] <foreign>is devoid of the knowledge of the master</foreign>.
4170</p>

.<p>Here is another example of that [improper disciple]: there is a man who is ordered to wear white garments by the teacher. 4200<p>Therefore, he is able to annihilate the sinful deeds, for all the social classes are annihilated by him.<note>The construction <foreign>hilaṅ ... denira</foreign> seems clumsy, as one would expect a regular passive construction like <foreign>hinilaṅ</foreign> (or <foreign>hinilaṅakәn</foreign>) ... <foreign>denira</foreign>. My interpretation revolves around the term <foreign>avakṣepa</foreign> (not attested in OJED), occurring both in the stanza and in the exegesis. 4270<p>This holy reality should be known by the learned master.</p><p rend="stanza" n="74">Conduct is the Power of Action, moral precept is known as [the Power of] Knowledge. The knower of the Supreme Reality knows this reality of the Siddhānta.

.
.<p>In short, the holy conduct is the Power of Action. The holy moral precept is the Power of Knowledge. If the learned master knows about the conduct and moral precept, he is called a <foreign>knower of reality</foreign>. He is accomplished in the holy scriptures of the Siddhānta.</p><p rend="stanza" n="75">The intelligent one, o Goddess, utters the syllables of the Siddhānta-Gnosis, characterized by seven divisions. The seven divisions are proclaimed.
.</p>
4275
.
.<p>The reality of the holy Siddhānta is the seven syllables. That is why [he] is accomplished.</p><p rend="stanza" n="76">The bhurloka is the first division, the <foreign>bhuvarloka</foreign> is the second, the <foreign>svarloka</foreign> is the third; [these are] standing on the Mahāloka, which is to be known as the fourth by the most excellent learned masters. Jana[loka] is the fifth, Tapo[loka] is the sixth, and Satyaloka is the seventh.<note>Here <foreign>saptadhā</foreign> seems to be used in the sense of ‘seventh’ instead of ‘sevenfold’. cf. supra, p. <ref>irregnumbers</ref>. On the correlation between the seven syllables, the Seven Worlds, and bodily parts, cf. JñS 26.5–10.</note>
.</p>
.
4280<p>The excellence of his discussion [is as follows:] at the beginning, he is king in the bhurloka. What is heard by him as the second [topic], he is king in the <foreign>bhuvarloka</foreign>. The third, he is king in the <foreign>svarloka</foreign>. The fourth, he is king in the Mahāloka. Further, as for the fifth, he is king in the Janaloka. What is heard by him as the sixth, he is king in the Tapoloka. The seventh, he is king in the Satyaloka. Such is the one who listens to the discussion of the holy doctrine on the Siddhānta-Gnosis.<note>The exegesis fancifully interprets the Sanskrit verse in the context of an exposition of seven topics heard by the practitioner, who thereby obtains lordship on the respective worlds.</note></p><p rend="stanza" n="77"><foreign>Thus the Siddhānta in [the form of] syllables has been proclaimed to be the Seven Worlds</foreign>.
.</p>
.
.<p>The one who listens to the discussion of the holy Siddhānta doctrine is king in the Seven Worlds.</p><p rend="stanza" n="78">The <hi rend="italic">sa</hi> is the bhurloka. The <hi rend="italic">i</hi> is the <foreign>bhuvarloka</foreign>. The <hi rend="italic">da</hi> is called Svar[loka]. The <hi rend="italic">dha</hi> is the Mahāloka.
.</p>
4285
.<p>The holy <hi rend="italic">sa</hi> is the bhurloka. The <hi rend="italic">i</hi> is the <foreign>bhuvarloka</foreign>. The <hi rend="italic">da</hi> is called <foreign>svarloka</foreign>. The <hi rend="italic">dha</hi> is the Mahāloka.</p><p rend="stanza" n="79">The <hi rend="italic">a</hi> is the Janaloka. The <hi rend="italic">na</hi> is the Tapoloka. The <hi rend="italic">ta</hi> is the Satyaloka. The Seven Worlds mean the body.
.</p>
.
.<p>The holy <hi rend="italic">a</hi> is the Janaloka. The <hi rend="italic">na</hi> is the Tapoloka. The <hi rend="italic">ta</hi> is the Satyaloka. They are the embodiment of the Lord Sadāśiva. He dissolves into the Lord Paramaśiva. The Unity dissolves into the reverend Free of Disease.</p><p rend="stanza" n="80">Blissful, supreme, subtle, benevolent (<foreign>śiva</foreign>), and eternal, o six-faced one: the unparalleled locus of the bile leads to the Supreme, o Goddess.
4290</p>
.
.<p>The reverend Free of Disease is eternally blissful.<note>The commentator construed <foreign>nityañ</foreign> with <foreign>ānandaṃ</foreign> instead of taking both as self-standing adjectives qualifying <foreign>pittasthānam</foreign>.</note> The holy bile is the locus of the reverend Free of Disease.</p><p rend="stanza" n="81">He who desires liberation, o Great Goddess, along with his children and his children’s kinsmen, [obtains] this supreme extinction as well as the eight supernatural powers.<note>I have diagnostically emended <foreign>asthānañ ca sukhāni ca</foreign> to <foreign>aṣṭāni ca guṇāni ca</foreign>.</note>
.</p>
.
4295<p>What is called the <foreign>extinction of Śiva</foreign> is the state of supreme independence.</p><p rend="stanza" n="82">Criminal<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>bhaksabhaksapeyapeya</ref></seg> acts,<note>In a legal context, as it can be evinced from the several attestations in Sanskrit literature, the <foreign>bahuvrīhi</foreign> compound <foreign>kr̥tadaṇḍa</foreign> (compare <foreign>dhr̥tadaṇḍa</foreign>) could be translated as ‘one who has received punishment’; however, it is likely that in this context the word was intended to means something like ‘acts for which punishment has been/may be carried out’.</note> anger, and even violence, according to his will: he acts as he pleases, o Goddess; he may perform both right and wrong.
.</p>
.
.<p>The nature of the learned master who knows the reverend Free of Disease is to perform the right and wrong. That is his act of free will.</p><p rend="stanza" n="83">Having<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>bhaksabhaksapeyapeya</ref></seg> enjoyed what can be eaten and what cannot be eaten, [i.e.] pure and impure [foods], and having drank liquor, the reverend sage wearing a chignon acts as he pleases, o tuft-haired one.
.</p>
4300
.<p>In short, the learned master should do whatever he pleases. He should not be hesitant toward all [those practices involving] the drinking of what should not be drunk, and the eating of what cannot be eaten. The eating of those [forbidden foods] is [performed] without hesitation.</p><p rend="stanza" n="84">Endowed<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>bhaksabhaksapeyapeya</ref></seg> with conduct and moral precepts, he acts as he pleases at all times.
.</p>
.
.<p>And the good moral precepts, it is his act of free will towards them.</p><p rend="stanza" n="85">The<seg cert="low">▷ <ref>bhaksabhaksapeyapeya</ref></seg> wise one who wears a chignon desires liberation, o Pārvatī. Free from conduct and moral precepts, he is taught [to be endowed with the Powers of] Action, Knowledge, and Pervasion.
4305</p>
.
.<p>The reality of the reverend Viṣṇu is one wearing a chignon. The reality of the reverend Brahmā is one whose head is shaven. The reality of the reverend Śiva is one wearing a tuft.<note>The commentator expanded on the verse by adding a series of correspondences between the attire of different categories of practitioners (<foreign>jaṭā</foreign>, <foreign>muṇḍī</foreign>, and <foreign>śikhā</foreign>) and the gods of the Trimūrti. While the <foreign>muṇḍī</foreign> type seems to be an addition, <foreign>śikhī</foreign> could reflect <foreign>śikhaṇḍī</foreign> in 11.83c, which I have emended into <foreign>śikhaṇḍin</foreign>, regarding it as a vocative constituting an epithet of Kumāra (‘wearing a tuft or lock of hair, tufted, crested; a peacock’, cf. Mann 2012: 205).</note> They are the Power of Knowledge,<note>I have supplied <foreign>jñānaśakti</foreign> in order to reflect the list of three items mentioned in the verse.</note> the Power of Action, and the Power of Pervasion.</p><p rend="stanza" n="86">This conduct is manifest, while moral precept is unmanifest indeed. This conduct is observance <foreign>(vrata)</foreign>, moral precept is virtue <foreign>(dharma)</foreign>.
.</p>
.
4310
.<p>The basic essentials<note>The word <foreign>simpәn</foreign>(<foreign>iṅ</foreign>) here seems to be used in the same sense as <foreign>saṅsipta</foreign>(<foreign>niṅ</foreign>). cf. 11.47.</note> of the modes of being of the holy Siddhānta are as follows. .</p>
.
.<p>Another [division] is as follows: <hi rend="italic">siddha</hi> is the reverend Rudra, <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> is Sadāśiva.</p><p rend="stanza" n="89"><hi rend="italic">siddha</hi> <foreign>is declared to be the Action</foreign>, <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> <foreign>is known as the Knowledge</foreign>.
4315</p>

.<p><hi rend="italic">siddha</hi> is the Power of Action, <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> is the Power of Knowledge.</p><p rend="stanza" n="90"><hi rend="italic">siddha</hi> <foreign>is to be known as Pervasion, while</foreign> <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> <foreign>as Sovereignty</foreign>.

4320<p><hi rend="italic">siddha</hi> is the Power of Pervasion, <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> is the Power of Sovereignty.</p><p rend="stanza" n="91"><hi rend="italic">si</hi> is to be known as Rudra, <hi rend="italic">ddha</hi> as Īśvara. <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> is taught to be Śiva. The praṇava is one only.
.</p>

.<p>The mode of being of the holy Siddhānta is threefold. <hi rend="italic">si</hi> is Rudra. <hi rend="italic">ddha</hi> ia Īśvara. <hi rend="italic">anta</hi> is Śiva. . <p>Gonda’s orthography has also been updated to conform to the standards of the DHARMA project. Hence <!--hyphens between the elements of compound words (both Sanskrit and Javanese) have been eliminated, and--> spaces have been eliminated between the definite article ṅ and the preceding word.</p>
. <p>The transition between sections 13 and 14 is not labelled here, because the encoder (AO) did not have access to the source edition of Gonda.</p>

In order to match the gloss katon, the stem should be udīkṣya, which is however unmetrical; therefore, I take uddīkṣya to be an Aiśa stem, m.c. One could imagine that the commentator confused it with uddiśya, but the parallel in JñS 25.4c speaks against this possibility. […] motion’.
MW glosses samīraṇa as ‘setting in motion, causing activity, stimulating, promoting’, etc. In 3.13 and 4.53, samīratva and samīraṇa are glossed as vāyu ‘wind’; cf. Abhi\-dhar\-ma\-ko\-śa 1.12 (p. 8): īraṇā vāyudhātuḥ| īryate ’nayā bhūtasroto..., ‘The element Wind is impulse; through that, the flow of elements is set in motion’. […] it.
I emend kāladehināṁ to kaladehinām, where kala- may be an elision for sakala: cf. the gloss °niṅ sarva māvak. Alternatively, one could understand kala (= kalā) as ‘discrete’ or ‘gross’. […]

Thus MWLex s.v. nirindriya, implying that Śiva has no body. cf. vigatendriyaḥ in 2.14.There […] exists.
Here nirindriya seems to be a pratīka quoting from pada b, but the gloss kinatayan ta sira deniṅ ṣoḍaśavikāra is likely to respond to nirvikāro in pada c (which, however, I understand in its general sense of ‘without modifications’, i.e. ‘unchangeable’). The meaning of yukti here seems to be akin to that of its Sanskrit counterpart, i.e. ‘application, practice, usage, means’ (note that the word derives from yuj, from which yoga also derives). […] crystal.

I take vinisr̥ta to be the same as viniḥsr̥ta, as recorded in MW (‘gone forth or out, issued forth, sprung from’, ‘escaped’). Often occurring kasurudan1fn in combination with sukhaduhkha (cf. 1.29, 4.34, 9.17, 10.2), kasurudan seems to mean ‘free from’, ‘devoid of’, ‘not affected by’, ‘abandoned by’. Rather than emending ’vyaktaṁ in the verse to vyāptaṁ (in the sense of vyāpakaṁ), I deem vyāpaka to be an idiosyncratic gloss of ’vyaktaṁ (which still expresses the idea that the supreme reality exists latently in all the beings, by pervasion). […] palate.
Nirānanda nirananda2 (lit. ‘non-joy’) is encountered in Śaiva texts (more often so in non-dualistic texts of the Trika, like the Tantrāloka and the Tantrasāra, often in association with śūnya) either as the second member of a series of six, following nijānanda (which could also provide a possible clue for emending this verse) and translated variously as ‘intense bliss’, ‘non-bliss’, or ‘bliss of stillness’: cf. According blinkingfn to MW, animeṣa is an equivalent of animiṣa, ‘not winking, looking steadily, vigilant’ (compare nirnimeṣa, ‘not twinkling, not closing the eye’), from nimiṣa, ‘shutting the eye, twinkling, winking [...] (also as a measure of time i.e. a moment’). In this context, i.e. after a series of expressions indicating the absence of divisions of time, this word was probably intended as ‘having no instants’; the exegesis glosses it as ‘there is no blinking in it’ (tan hana kәḍap iriya).
